PART 1 KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT 18 We often think of knowledge management as a practice reserved for students. For those who need to cram vast amounts of knowledge to pass exams and complete assignments. We seldom think of knowledge management on an individual or professional level. You are different. Something has drawn you to this book. Maybe you are that student, who wants to figure out how to get through vast amounts of learning material and ace your assignments. Maybe you’re a working professional who has discovered that a knowledge system is the key to being better at what you do. Or maybe you’re like me, an autodidact, who loves to learn and be curious, and a knowledge system is the only way to remember what you’ve discovered. Regardless of your goals, this book will give you everything you need to create a powerful knowledge system that will be valuable for a lifetime. What is knowledge management? It’s important to make sure that we’re on the same page when it comes to what knowledge management is. Knowledge management is one or more methods to capture, organise, consume, comprehend and reflect on information that is meaningful to you. A great knowledge management system can help you with two main aspects of how you learn and process information: • Divergent thinking—Where you explore and open your mind to new ideas. This is achieved by asking questions, exploring multiple perspectives and keeping your learning broad. • Convergent thinking—Where you start to reduce your thinking to more concrete ideas that have been critically assessed. WHAT IS KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 19 Your knowledge management skills will give you the ability to perform both divergent and convergent thinking. The goal is not to just make your knowledge accessible, but also actionable. As the author of this book, my goal is not to help you create the perfect knowledge system, but rather help you to go on and do great things. Knowledge management is like learning to read. It becomes the gateway to learning anything. Knowledge management is vital There’s a lot of information out there. An awful lot. Too much. Some of it is useful, some of it is harmful, some of it is a distraction. But you cannot deny that we’re in the information overload era. Knowing how to manage this is a crucial skill. You want to be able to navigate the world and remain calm, collected and in control. This however does not happen by default. You’re forever being told what to think. Information can be used as a tool to weaponize and influence your behaviour. You become quick to judge and good luck having any sensible discussion on the topic. Only an active effort of managing your knowledge can bring order to the chaos. The only viable alternative is to turn it off completely. Not many people consider that knowledge management is a skill that can be improved. It’s easy to have this innate trust that if we hear something, we’ll remember it. But that is rarely the case. And if we do, we struggle to remember it accurately. How can you be someone who can speak with confidence and authority? How can you be someone who has a great memory and be a fountain of insight and wisdom? You want your voice to be heard and your opinions to be valued. KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT IS VITAL 20 You need a system to manage your knowledge. If you don’t have one, you’ll continue drifting in the status quo of mediocrity. Stark words I know, but I stand by them. Take knowledge workers for example. One of the most fascinating things is that they don’t look to improve their knowledge management skills—ironic given the label. Now compare this to being an athlete. They are continually looking for ways to improve their skills. They use deliberate practice—where they stretch themselves just beyond their own level of competency to push their abilities beyond what they are currently capable of. Knowledge workers do not do this. As Cal Newport puts it in So Good They Can’t Ignore You: “Musicians, athletes, and chess players know all about deliberate practice. Knowledge workers, however, do not. This is great news for knowledge workers: If you can introduce this strategy into your working life you can vault past your peers in your acquisition of career capital.” You want to become better at your craft. You want to open up your mind. You want to improve your communication skills. You want to become a leader. You want to become your own boss. Whatever it is that you want to improve, you have skills to learn. You need a system to do it, and do it at a level that will outpace your peers and set you apart. Knowledge management isn’t just useful in your professional life. Imagine you or a loved one becomes sick. You find yourself dealing with lots of information that you don’t know what it means. You put the trust in others to make decisions for you. But you ultimately have to make the decisions. What do you base it on? The myriad of discussions, snippets of understanding and contradictory opinions? A knowledge system in this scenario is vital to making informed decisions. KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT IS VITAL 21 I will never understand why we don’t take a notepad when we visit the doctor. Having a knowledge management system will help you remember more. It will give you the confidence to think better and use your knowledge for a greater good. But most importantly, you’ll have the bug of curiosity and it will be a way of expressing that passion. It will be fun. “The cure to boredom is curiosity. There is no cure for curiosity.”—Dorothy Parker Who benefits from knowledge management? Anyone can benefit from knowledge management. Let’s explore some examples. For the undergraduate student You’re a student at university. You have many class lectures and lots of books to read. The measure of your work is done through assignments and exams. In the classroom you’ll be presented with slides, handouts and chapters to read. You have a lot of information to consume. But remember, it’s not just about copying and pasting the content into your notes. You need to understand it. After all, it’s much easier to remember something you understand than something you don’t. Your goal as a student is to organise your information in such a way that you can create revision cards for exams and reference material for assignments. Spaced repetition is a great way to test yourself until it is etched in your brain’s memory. WHO BENEFITS FROM KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 22 With an atomic note-taking system, your notes become the building block to writing your assignments. The ‘thinking’ has already been done. You just have to put the words together. A great note-taking system however will not only help you achieve this, but it will also help you understand the material better. You’ll be able to ask better questions and connect ideas. And the best part, when your studies are complete, they won’t just be a collection of degrading memories, but you’ll have your notes in a system that will be accessible and relevant for a lifetime to come. For the PHD student As a doctoral student your primary focus is to consider many different sources of information and make sense of them. You need to compare them and question their insights. Only when you have enough understanding can you see potential problems to solve. Problems which have never been solved before. And problems that you will go on to solve. To do this, you’ll be consuming lots of papers, books and journals. You need a system that will allow you to bring them all together so they are accessible on one canvas for you to perform your thinking. As you start to hypothesise, you need your notes stored in such a way that you’re not continually sifting through massive documents each time. You need your references broken down into atomic notes making it easy to use. Your knowledge system must enable you to ask questions to validate your understanding or theorise a new insight. By asking these questions you will identify the gaps in your own knowledge. This will direct your research to find the answer you need. You will later use your knowledge system as the atomic building blocks to author your own research papers. WHO BENEFITS FROM KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 23 For the teacher As a teacher your role is to help your students gain both knowledge and understanding of the subject. By having your material stored in a knowledge management system, you will be able to evolve it each academic year to ensure the feedback from past students are incorporated in the learning process. The atomic nature of your knowledge system means you can take the core learning blocks and allow it to be repackaged in many different ways. You may use them in a slide deck, handout sheet, virtual seminar, group exercise, project assignments or even exam questions. You can start to ask questions about your teaching methods to find the optimal way that your students engage with the material. How would you teach the concept as a group exercise? What knowledge should a student have prior to understanding the topic? What terminology would a student be familiar with? Where do they keep getting confused? Your knowledge system not only contains the material for the subject, but the meta notes to help teach it to your students. It doesn’t have to be limited to just yourself. You can share this with other teachers and assistants so the benefits can spread far and wide. Most importantly, by adopting these techniques, you become a better teacher. You learn how to engage your students with the material which improves their experience and understanding. And with a great system, you enjoy the art of teaching and the subjects you are passionate to teach even more. This in turn benefits everyone. For the content creator You’re a content creator. Maybe you write on your blog, create educational content or make YouTube videos. You want to share WHO BENEFITS FROM KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 24 expert insights to your audience on topics that resonate with them. You want to be a voice of trust and authority. Your end goal may be to make a business around your true passions, or to help create a movement by inspiring the next generation of thinking. Whatever it is, you need a knowledge strategy to communicate clearly, concisely and with expertise. An atomic note-taking system can help you build up a wealth of knowledge that can generate endless content ideas. It can help you move away from the heavy lift of one idea at a time, to having many ideas developing simultaneously—whether that be a blog post, YouTube video or ebook. You can use your knowledge system to start exploring how to communicate better, how to improve your reach and how to master the skills required to create engaging content that people love. Most importantly, it helps you become a deep thinker with a consistent output that builds trust and authority. For the entrepreneur Being an entrepreneur means that you need to learn a lot of different skills, and all at the same time. You turn to books on entrepreneurship, marketing, leadership, product development and fundraising. It’s endless. How do you go from being a content consumer to an action taker with this new knowledge? To do that you need a knowledge system that allows you to filter and organise the information that is relevant to what you need. Your knowledge system will allow you to capture the key insights from a vast array of books and articles. You use it to capture industry specific insights that can help you build a better product and marketing strategy. WHO BENEFITS FROM KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 25 Want to create a pitch deck? Quickly find the insights and material you’ve worked on over the preceding months. Need the market insights, competitor landscape and user trends? Find the notes and drop them in. What about the product or service itself? You can create insights about what it should do, the mindset of your customers, the language they use and the needs they have. All this can be documented within your knowledge system. And as a business owner, you will be faced with many challenges where you have to make difficult decisions. By using journaling, you can think through your decision making. Things like how to hire your first employee, or do a disciplinary. It allows you to have the tools you need when you need them and be consistent in your approach time and time again. For the programmer Learning a programming language or keeping up to date with tech can be challenging. It’s easy to fall into the trap of following tutorials, but find yourself stumped when you try to apply them to your own projects. You understand it, but you just don’t have the ability to recall it. A great knowledge system allows you to capture the code snippets you discover so you can find them effortlessly when you’re programming. Technical guides can be created and shared with your team. Software patterns and principles can be captured so you can evaluate the best solution to the problem and use it when it’s appropriate. As you work with tech, you may pick up small tips or encounter errors. These can be documented so you can refer back to it again in the future. And for those who are keen to share your knowledge publicly, a knowledge system allows you to create blog posts and share your insights on social media. WHO BENEFITS FROM KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENT? 26 For the autodidact For the autodidacts—those who love to self learn—a knowledge system is perfect for you to explore the world through the lens of your curiosity. Organise the books, articles, quotes and ideas you encounter. Connect your ideas together. Create original thinking by expanding on the knowledge you’ve discovered. Become a polymath with wide knowledge and understanding. Share your thoughts. Connect with like minded people. Teach the world. Your knowledge system will allow you to be unconstrained and go where your curiosity takes you. Externalisation of your thoughts A knowledge system helps you externalise your knowledge. Sometimes this may be referred to as a second brain. A place where you can look up your notes without having to remember everything. Imagine you’ve read a great book. It made so much sense to you as you read it. But for some reason, when you want to recall those great moments and insights, you draw a blank. This is a recognition vs recall problem. You know it, you just can’t recall it, but if you saw it again, it would come back to you. As you read content where it all makes sense, you assume you’ll remember it. Your feeling in the moment doesn’t give you the urgency to capture the information for future use. It’s only when you try to recall what you read in the past do you realise that you just can’t remember it. This is called passive consumption. With active consumption, you create notes on what you learn. Now when you want to recall it, you can look it up. When you write your notes in your own words, you improve your ability to recall the information again. EXTERNALISATION OF YOUR THOUGHTS 27 A great knowledge system is optimised for your ability to recall information from it at a later date. Otherwise you’re just creating an archival system and not a thinking system. “Your mind is for having ideas, not holding them.”― David Allen The different types of note-taking The knowledge system this book is about is the Zettelkasten method. We’ll go into more detail about its concepts and how it works, then see examples of how to apply it. It’s however important to mention other types of note-taking methods and how they are different to the Zettelkasten method. The 5 categories of note-taking methods Each of the different note-taking methods can be summarised into the following approaches. • Capture focused—Do they aim to capture the material? For example with the Charting, Sentence, Mind Mapping and Outline method, along with Bullet Journaling and Daily Notes. • Organisation—Does it help you organise your information and related concepts? For example with Flow and Box note-taking. • Summarisation—Do they aim to distil the information? For example with the Cornell or DaVinci method. • Understanding—Can you understand the information in its simplest form? For example the Feynman Technique and the SQ3R method. • Thinking—Does it enable you to have original thoughts and insights? This is what the Zettelkasten method solves. THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING 28 Capture focused note-taking Outline method Your notes are a series of hierarchical bullet points. This is referred to as an outline. The benefit of this method is that you can collapse the bullet points to get a helicopter view of your notes, then expand the bullets to get a detailed view. Charting method This method allows you to list multiple topics on your page as rows in a table. Then on the columns you can track things like the advantages, disadvantages and when you should use it. You can then make notes on multiple topics at the same time by filling out the relevant cells on the grid as they are discussed. Sentence method This method aims to capture the main details of a talk. It’s similar to highlighting a book where you capture the key sentences that are relevant to your learning. What you end up with is a condensed version of the original material. This method is very useful to capture fleeting notes for topics that are happening in real-time when you don’t have the time to properly think about them. Mind Mapping Similar to outlining, your ideas and notes are captured as nodes on a mind map. Each node can have children nodes which can express more detail on the key point. THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING 29 Bullet Journaling Similar to outlining, the Bullet Journaling method is where you use bullet points to capture your thoughts, tasks, insights and details. It is a mixture of task management and knowledge management. Daily Notes Daily Notes help you create the routine of note-taking. You can mix this with something like Bullet Journaling where every day you capture your fleeting thoughts and priorities to help you focus the day. Organisation based note-taking Flow method This method is designed to help you learn while you’re consuming the source material, including creating notes within a class lecture. Rather than transcribing the source material, you use arrows to indicate the flow of information to connect the concepts together. You write your notes in your own words, add diagrams for visual references and make connections between concepts. Box method This is a digital first note-taking method which uses boxes to separate out the topics from the source material. This makes it easy to review later on and is great for visual learners as each box can be accompanied by a small doodle or diagram. It’s not easy to do during live learning and is usually done by creating a more aesthetically pleasing set of notes when time permits. THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING 30 Summarisation based note-taking Cornell System This note-taking method is where the page is split up into two columns (30% and 70%) with a header and footer. The header will be the title of the topic. The 30% left column will be where you store your keywords and questions. The main 70% on the right column will be where you make your main notes and key thoughts. The footer is where you summarise your notes making it ideal for revision exercises. DaVinci method This is very similar to the Cornell System but it includes more doodles and illustrations of the topic. Understanding based note-taking Feynman Technique Not strictly a note-taking method, the Feynman Technique is based on the principle that if you cannot explain it simply, then you do not understand it. Your goal is to simplify your notes by removing jargon words, complicated sentences and confusing concepts. You review your notes by asking whether a 12 year old could understand it. If not, you keep simplifying it. SQ3R method This refers to Survey, Question, Read, Recite and Review. This is commonly used when reading material such as text books. It is quite THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING 31 an active form of note-taking where you have to properly survey the source material. You start by scanning the material to orient yourself with the subject. It gives you a feel for what type of information it holds and the questions it can help answer. As you then read the material in more depth, you aim to use the material to answer the questions you have. The goal is to be able to recite the information and confirm your understanding through a review process. There are extensions to SQ3R with SQ4R and SQ5R which add additional steps in the method. Thinking based note-taking The Zettelkasten note-taking method The Zettelkasten method is a free flowing note-taking system that can be adapted to suit your individual preferences. It consists of writing atomic notes and a workflow that helps move these notes through the system. These atomic notes can be ever changing and added to over time. It is a form of collecting ideas and information. As a note-taking system, it is not like what we experienced in school where we try to create a condensed version of the source material. Instead, it is a way to map understanding to how our mind works. The Zettelkasten method is the primary focus of this book. It provides a framework of which you can consume your source material, organise notes, connect ideas and generate original thought. It is possible to mix some of the other note-taking methods with the Zettelkasten method. For example, outlining is a very popular method to use with the Zettelkasten. As you start to explore the Zettelkasten method, you might choose to blend your approach to create a workflow that best suits your needs. THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING 32 Zettelkasten is unique to other forms of note-taking because it allows you to connect ideas together. It’s a map where anything can relate to anything. Other note-taking methods are usually a way to present information of a single topic, not consider the information in the system as a whole. You may see this referred to the following names: • Atomic Note-Taking—This is the name of this book and is more accessible than using the German word Zettelkasten to non- German speakers. It highlights the atomic nature of note-taking and its emergent properties that great structures are derived from its atomic parts. • Smart Notes—This is another name for the Zettelkasten method and has been popularised by the book How to Take Smart Notes by Sönke Ahrens. • Second Brain—You may hear of the Zettelkasten method being referred to as a ‘Second Brain’. This really just refers to the externalisation of your thinking into your note-taking system so you are free to have ideas but not store them in your head. Building a Second Brain It is worth noting that you may discover the concept of Building a Second Brain (BASB). This is the product of Tiago Forte. It’s a technique of organising your work using the PARA method. PARA meaning Projects, Areas, Resources and Archive. If you’re a knowledge worker, this is a great method of organising both ongoing projects, but also areas of interest. However, unlike the Zettelkasten, it doesn’t directly solve the issue of how to extract and organise knowledge from source materials to create original thinking. THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF NOTE-TAKING PART 2 THE ZETTELKASTEN METHOD What is the Zettelkasten? Imagine you’re living in a pre-computer era. You’re passionate about many subjects ranging from economy to love. You have a deep interest in these topics and you want to find the secrets they hold. You want to develop new ideas. Ideas that you can share with the world. To do this, you need a system. A system where you can organise your thoughts. A system that helps you think. A system where you can connect ideas together. A system that helps you discover new and innovative solutions to deep questions. A system that makes it effortless to distil ideas into something you’re excited to publish. Without the help of digital aids, you are armed with a pile of 6” x 4” blank index cards, a filing cabinet and a pen. Your name is Niklas Luhmann—a 25 year old German sociologist— who in 1952 created such a system we now refer to as the Zettelkasten. Luhmann went on to write more than 70 books and nearly 400 scholarly articles. The subjects of his work range from law, economy, and politics—to—art, religion, and love. Even after his death, others were able to use his note-taking system to publish new works. WHAT IS THE ZETTELKASTEN? 35 The Zettelkasten is a German word that means “slip box” (or “note box”). At its simplest, this is the technique of storing your notes in an organised way. Notes would be numbered in a sequence (often referred to as the Folgezettel). Notes in a sequence can be branched off into tangent ideas. Interesting connections between any two notes can be added by a reference from one note to another. The main benefits There are a variety of benefits to the Zettelkasten note-taking system over more traditional note-taking methods. These can be summarised as follows: • A bottom up approach—original ideas emerge from the connections you make creating new insights and understanding • Clarify your understanding—by writing simply, you iterate and improve your level of understanding • Perform deep thinking—by considering each note’s implication to other notes, you perform a deeper level of thinking • Pass through your own filter—as you’re not simply copying the source material, each note passes through your own thinking to ensure it’s relevant, understandable and useful • Easy to refresh your understanding—the atomic nature of each note means you can quickly recall its contents • Assemble projects—create a first draft of any project by assembling an outline from existing atomic notes • Ask questions—find gaps in your understanding by asking new questions and see which atomic notes can help provide the answer WHAT IS THE ZETTELKASTEN? • Provides a workflow—it helps you go through the process of capturing, understanding, organising, all the way to developing new insights • Emergence of structure—as you add more notes, you’ll be able to see which ideas are clustering together Zettelkasten versus The Commonplace An alternative to the Zettelkasten could be the Commonplace. The Commonplace has been around since the 1600’s and is a way to compile knowledge and inspiration into a single book. It’s been used by many authors where they would collect their inspiration and knowledge in a single place. They would then use it as a reference when writing a new book. The Zettelkasten differs in that it doesn’t just compile knowledge, but allows you to create a whole sphere of understanding. You get to ‘think’ as you go through the process of writing, questioning, and linking your notes. WHAT IS THE ZETTELKASTEN? The Commonplace A commonplace might be a collection of notes, photos, documents, etc Or it could be a book where everything is collated containing ideas, references, quotes, etc 37 Zettelkasten concepts The Zettelkasten method consists of two main parts: 1. The system—how to represent, organise, link, and store your notes 2. The workflow—how to add and maintain notes within the system through a defined way of working Within the system, there are three primary note types: 1. Fleeting notes—these are your quick ideas and things you want to capture such as book highlights, quotes, etc. They can also be the raw notes from any material you consume before you have the chance to really think about it. 2. Literature notes—these are your atomic notes derived from your fleeting notes on a given source material. Each set of literature notes will be scoped to the specific source material, for example a single book or a video course. 3. Permanent notes—These are your master set of atomic notes which now cover all material you’ve consumed and any ideas you’ve added. As you process your literature notes to create permanent notes, you will now consider the wider impact the notes have in the context of your whole set of permanent notes. Some will refer to fleeting notes as the temporary ideas you have, and literature notes as the notes you make directly from reading books or other material. During my exploration of the Zettelkasten, I have found that my preferred method of working is to create fleeting notes first from books and other material, and then convert these to literature notes as a secondary action. It’s not to say that any approach is wrong. I just wanted to point out the difference to avoid any confusion if you have looked at any other explanations of the Zettelkasten method. The Zettelkasten system Each note in your Zettelkasten should be atomic. This means you should aim for one single idea in each note. Wait, just one single idea? Yep. The motivation behind it is relatively simple. The simpler the idea, the easier it is for you to reason about, recall, link to, and reuse in any new projects. It’s important to note that a single idea doesn’t just mean a single sentence. It can be multiple paragraphs containing an explanation from different perspectives, a counter argument, questions to think about or include examples of how to use it. But the whole note is really one core idea with supporting information to help explain it. Let’s take a simple example. You’re learning about critical thinking and you want to include a definition in your notes. This may be useful if you need to introduce what critical thinking is in a blog post, or maybe you simply want to remind yourself in the future. THE ZETTELKASTEN SYSTEM 40 So what’s included in this note: • A title—there is a simple title. In this case, it is a top level definition of what critical thinking is. • The contents—in this example, it’s a brief description of the topic critical thinking. The contents can of course be a range of things. We’ll cover this in more detail later. Next you want to create additional notes around the topic of critical thinking. You’ll start to feel that they build on each other. This is where you can consider them to be a sequence. In traditional note-taking, these additional notes would usually be stored in one larger document and potentially placed under different sub headings. The goal we’re trying to achieve is not to have large documents, but rather break things up into their atomic parts. This is how we can achieve the ‘Zettelkasten magic’ by linking notes together and thinking more deeply about these individual parts. Personally, I like to refer to these note sequences as continuation notes. While they are indeed a sequence, referring to them as a continuation allows us to understand that the ideas contained within the notes actually relate and build on each other. Expanding the example of critical thinking, we might continue from the definition note to include notes about the techniques, benefits and even origin. The result is a set of atomic notes within our note-taking system organised in a sequence. THE ZETTELKASTEN SYSTEM 43 By having your notes written atomically, you can pinpoint the exact ideas that are directly relevant. For example, you may have a note titled “The Socratic Method: The reasons for opposition”. You get to see the existing note on the socratic method through a new lens of the fixed mindset. You get to think deeply about the connection. The alternative approach would be to write longer documents containing all your notes. You simply don’t have time to read through it, let alone figure out how to link to just the bit you need. You’d be tempted to copy and paste the section you want out of the note and into your new note. Doing so means you’re duplicating your work making it harder to track what to update should your understanding on the topic change. Having a single idea on a note means it’s easy to find, easy to recap what it means, easy to update and easy to link to. This is why we recommend one idea per note. The Zettelkasten workflow One of the unique advantages of the Zettelkasten note-taking system is that it has a workflow that guides how knowledge moves into the system. You start with fleeting notes, expand these to literature notes, and then process them to permanent notes. THE ZETTELKASTEN WORKFLOW fleeting, literature and permanent note workflow Notes are stored in a slip box (Zettelkasten in German) Create condensed fleeting notes when reading create atomic literature notes from the day’s reading Consider existing permanent notes Create new or updated permanent notes 1 2 3 4 5 49 Fleeting notes Fleeting notes are your temporary ideas before they have been fully refined. These could be simple thoughts you want to capture, daily notes, social media posts you’ve seen or quotes from a book. If you’re familiar with shower thoughts—those random fleeting ideas that spark a moment of true inspiration often had when taking a shower— those are fleeting notes as they evaporate just as quickly as they come. I also consider the raw notes I take when reading a book or watching a video to be fleeting notes. I’m simply capturing what is relevant, adding my own fleeting thoughts and moving on. I’m not thinking too deeply about the subject matter at this stage. Fleeting notes should be short lived. They exist to capture the idea in the moment. They should not be used as a way to store ideas or be used as a reference. They can end up unorganised and chaotic and finding what you need when you need it is near impossible. It’s reasonable to assume that a lot of people who take notes but haven’t really considered note-taking as a skill, end up collecting lots of fleeting notes that sit there gaining digital dust in their notes app of choice. I too am guilty of this. We often make notes from a video course, make highlights from the Kindle app or create handwritten notes in a lecture. These are the raw fleeting notes where you’ve captured the information as it’s presented with a quick decision to determine if it is useful or relevant. What’s important to mention here is that your fleeting notes are a quick capture of what’s important to you. You distil the information to just the useful parts, such as in a bullet point list, but with enough information to allow you to write what it means in your own words at a later time. Once you have your fleeting notes, it’s time to start processing these into literature notes. FLEETING NOTES 50 Literature notes Imagine you’ve read a book and you have a lot of highlights, quotes, questions, ideas, and thoughts. These are your fleeting notes that you’ve captured from the book. Now you want to organise your understanding. You can think of this like writing a book summary. A condensed version of the book that makes sense to you. Your goal is to use these fleeting notes to create a collection of atomic literature notes that show you understand the subject without having to refer back to the original book. To do this, you create a sequence of notes, where each note expresses one single idea from the book. LITERATURE NOTES Fleeting notes of the book Atomic Habits using the outline method 51 Each note you create might contain a definition, example, opinion, conflict, idea or question. Avoid confirmation bias The idea that literature notes are created from fleeting notes, and being scoped only to the source material may differ from other approaches to the Zettelkasten method. Personally, I like the idea that you first create fleeting notes from the books you read, then literature notes. I also like the idea that your literature notes are a self contained set of atomic notes just for that source material. The reason to scope the literature notes to the source material is to avoid having any bias from any previous material you’ve studied. You want to assess the new material for its merits alone and not make judgements too quickly. To give you an analogy, imagine you’re studying the subject of wizardry. You first read Harry Potter and try to understand the magical system, abilities, and the role and influence wizards have. You make your literature notes exploring these concepts and your understanding around it. LITERATURE NOTES Pinned fleeting note Creation of atomic literature notes 52 Later, you read The Lord of the Rings to continue your study of wizardry. But you find yourself looking at wizardry through the lens of Harry Potter as that’s what you know. You keep finding differences and conflicts making it harder to reason about. It’s time consuming and clouds your judgement. In some cases, you may find that you desire seeing the world through a Harry Potter lens. Your earlier exposure and familiarity makes it your favourite and you’re trying to find the information that proves Harry Potter’s perspective of wizardry, and not The Lord of the Rings. You start to dismiss information that doesn’t agree with this. You suffer a confirmation bias and miss out on properly seeing The Lord of the Rings for what it truly is. To overcome this, when you study The Lord of the Rings, write your literature notes only from the perspective of The Lord of The Rings and pretend that Harry Potter doesn’t exist. This frees your mind to consider it exactly as it is. It doesn’t matter if it conflicts with Harry Potter. You want to consider that either book might have the better representation of wizardry. Later, you will create your permanent notes from these literature notes. Only then do you compare and contrast the differences and similarities between the different ideologies. Both ideologies should have equal weight in your mind and should not be unfairly influenced by any cognitive bias you had when making the notes. 53 This is why I propose that fleeting notes and literature notes are made in the context of the material they come from. Yes, that includes writing atomic literature notes to fully explore your understanding without a clouded judgement. It helps reduce the bias you will naturally have and give you a truer perspective of material. In this case, either go back to the source material to try to seek an answer, or create an atomic note highlighting what it is you don’t understand. This provides an opportunity for you to have open questions in your Zettelkasten that research from other sources might be able to answer. Other times, you may perfectly understand the material you’re making literature notes about, but think of questions to expand your thinking to explore new directions. [[Why habits are hard to stick to]] 55 Permanent notes Your slip box is a large collection of atomic notes. Slip box notes are called permanent notes. These notes are the most recent representation of your understanding and are interconnected with notes that are related. To create permanent notes, you base them off your literature notes. This means you pick up a set of literature notes you haven’t already processed, go through them one by one, and add it to your slip box as a permanent note. At first it may feel that you’re just copying your literature notes and placing the copies in your slip box and calling them permanent notes. However, as you build up more and more permanent notes, every new literature note you process is to be considered in the context of the whole slip box. I like to think of a note as a single idea that it expresses. So when you process a literature note, you need to consider if the idea expressed is brand new to your slip box, or if you have covered it elsewhere. You start to ask, “Do I already have this idea?”, or “What notes do I have that this idea relates to?” If the idea is new, add it as a new permanent note in your slip box. However, if the idea has already been covered, you must now consider if you need to make any changes to the notes in your slip box, or if it is already covered. Those changes might be to add more clarity to the idea, or to counter argue the idea if you now have opposing information. The goal of processing literature notes into your permanent notes is not to copy the notes as they are, but to merge the ideas they convey. As you process these ideas into your slip box, also think about which notes you can relate it to. Think of this process like learning a new skill, for example filmmaking. Every new idea that you learn, you can relate it to knowledge you already have. This might be knowledge PERMANENT NOTES 56 about photography such as lenses, shutter speed, and aperture. Or it might be about storytelling such as writing, acting, and dialogue. If you imagine your slip box as your externalised thinking system, then consider adding permanent notes as a way to upgrade your thinking. How to process a literature note into a new permanent note You may be wondering what you do with your literature notes. Do you edit them and turn them into permanent notes? Or do you make a copy and add permanent notes as new notes? Personally, I like to take a copy as it leaves the original literature note intact. This is helpful if I want to refer back to the source material in the future. Sometimes I may have misunderstood something or I need to clarify it further. Being able to trace my steps back to the source material helps me find the original information for me to review again. When you’re finished with the literature note, you can then archive it to indicate that it has been processed. By making a copy, it means you can continue to make modifications to the permanent notes from other sources of information. This lets you evolve your thinking in your permanent notes, but keep your literature notes in their original form. Reference your literature note You never know when your ideas may be challenged in the future. It’s frustrating when you lose sight of how you came up with your ideas and who was the catalyst that sparked them. This can be solved by making sure your permanent notes reference the literature notes they were based on. PERMANENT NOTES 57 In your permanent note, create a ‘References’ section and add any links to the literature notes that helped you write the permanent notes. If you ever need to cite a source or revisit the original material for clarification, you can follow these references and get the information you need. An example permanent note PERMANENT NOTES Arrival Fallacy We often set arbitrary goals for us to achieve. This might be to pass an exam, or to lose weight for a wedding. However, once you reach those goals, you find that there is nothing further to strive for. The goal is complete. You have arrived. And your motivation to continue the habits that achieved this goal go away. This is known as the Arrival Fallacy. You believe that happiness will be when you arrive at your goal. But happiness often fades quickly after the goal has been achieved. So you end up changing to new goals. You end up needing to make new habits. This constant flux of different goals makes it harder to build your [[Identity-Driven Habits]] around what you do and to have robust set of [[System-Driven Habits]]. Without a long running set of goals, you can end up feeling aimless, unmotivated and frustrated. See also 1. [[Why habits are hard to stick to]] References 1. Make the necessary changes and add an additional reference pointing to the literature note that inspired the changes. What do you do about question literature notes? During the creation of your literature notes, you may have recorded some questions that you want to explore and try to answer. Now is the time to consider each question to see if you can find a meaningful answer from your entire set of permanent notes. To do this, start by gathering together the notes that are potentially relevant and then see if they are useful to help find an answer. An example might be notes you have on how the body responds to stress. In your literature notes, you may discover that the part of the brain called the amygdala is responsible for processing emotions and memories associated with fear. When you created your literature notes, you may have thought about its relationship to imposter syndrome. When you now process your literature notes into permanent notes, you find this question: “Is imposter syndrome a form of stress and is the amygdala responsible for triggering it?” To try and answer this question, you can look for any existing notes you have about the amygdala, imposter syndrome and emotional triggers. You can review these notes with a goal in mind: “How does this relate to stress and the processing of emotions and fear?”. PERMANENT NOTES 60 You might conclude that imposter syndrome may be a fear where negative emotional memories are associated with it. You may consider that stressful situations can trigger these memories and create the sensation of imposter syndrome. You may even conclude that imposter syndrome is an anxiety that causes stress but isn’t a symptom of stress. This anxiety could be triggered by some other non-obvious factors. You’re left with a hypothesis. It opens up the pathway for more research on the subject. You might even consider how you could conduct your own research to seek a more complete answer. You can start to consider what would help prove or disprove this theory. Often though, your questions will highlight the gaps in your understanding. This is where you can look for new material to research such as books or journals. As you study this new material, these questions will help you scan for information that can help provide an answer. This gives your research a goal, making it easier and more enjoyable to read. If you don’t create open questions and try to answer them, you will miss out. Many original and insightful ideas will remain completely undiscovered. The slip box The slip box refers to the place where you store your permanent notes. In an analogue Zettelkasten, this would be a physical filing cabinet, where the notes would be numbered in a sequence and placed inside. THE SLIP BOX 61 In a digital Zettelkasten, we refer to the slip box as the place where you store your notes within your chosen note-taking application. These could be files in folders on your computer, or notes stored within an application database. Unlike an analogue system, a digital system has the benefit of finding notes using search, hashtags or by clicking on links to other notes. The simplest way to think about the slip box is that it is the place where your permanent notes are stored. Article link: https://meda.io/why-do-i-get-motivated-but-never-do-anything/ Why do I get motivated, but never do anything? As I further explore the traits and habits that successful and happy people have, I have observed that it is not uncommon for individuals to get motivated by a new goal, but then take no steps to do it [Highlight: This emphasises the problem that people don’t take action]. Reflecting on my own experience and of those who I encounter, it is a perplexing and saddening affair to watch one's dreams dissipate into nothingness. What is it that is preventing us from working hard, developing our craft and gaining mastery of our skill? What is it that throws us off track to the point where we give up and move onto something else? Is it just bad habits? Is it laziness? Did we really want it at all, or was it all just a wish without any real commitment? Are we just being hard on ourselves [Comment : Is this true, are we being hard on ourselves, and if so, what does that look like?] or do we just lack the confidence to accept the failures [Comment : Being able FLEETING NOTES BY EXAMPLE 102 to accept and confront our failures without affecting our confidence or self esteem is a critical trait to having the courage to take action] and overcome them triumphantly? As I seek to answer this, I uncover a phenomenon called motioning, or to be in motion rather than in action [Highlight: Key theme mentioned here]. Imagine you want to become a better writer. You read a few articles about writing techniques, then you find an online training course on the subject. This feels great as you're gaining a new perspective and knowledge on the subject which you previously did not have. Your motivation peaks and you get excited so you turn to social media to announce your new found passion and goal — to write a book [Highlight: Emphasising this as it’s a way to visualise the traits someone has when they exhibit motioning]. You may even plan out a few chapters and a catchy title. You then retire for the night and feel pumped and positive. Tomorrow will be the start of your new found path. Morning arrives and as you wake, you slip right into your previous routine [Comment : This happens all too often. We have the ambition to make a change, but we fail to set a new habit or routine to make the change happen. How can we focus on new habits when we have motivation?]. The groggy memory of the excitement last night starts to fade. You still feel positive, but real life is calling you back to the fray. The day is tiring, and your new learning and book become passive thoughts when you have a spare moment. The days pass, then weeks. You feel a sense of guilt [Highlight: This is capturing the emotions that signal motioning] that you haven't acted on the thing you announced very proudly on social media. You regard those articles on writing as critical assets, the doorway that lights the path to your new future life once again. You're scared to close those precious few browser tabs that keep your dream alive. You eventually close them and they are lost forever, along with your dream of being a writer. FLEETING NOTES BY EXAMPLE 103 As dramatic as this scenario may be, we all face this type of challenge. We have a spark of motivation which is crucial to finding a new path, but we often act hastily [Highlight: This adds context to what actions lead to failure]. We are ill equipped to turn motivation into a habit [Comment : This is introducing that habits play a role in relation to motivation] — a habit that will carry us to achieving our goal. This is motioning — all intent and no action [Highlight: A catchy summary of motioning]. The worst part is that our brain is not well equipped to tell the difference between actually achieving, or the mere intent to achieve, our goal. [Comment : Where did this statement originate from, what science backs it up?] The sheer fact that we broadcast our intention, collect articles and make a plan is enough for our brain to feel good, so we stop taking action [Comment : Can I spot this trait in my own experience?]. We were in motion, but yielded no action — and our brain tricked us. The good news however is that this is completely normal behaviour. We are often blind to its presence, but once we recognise it, we can do something about it. So let's explore how we can avoid the act of motioning, and start doing. Avoid extrinsic rewards [Highlight: Key solution point] We want to avoid putting our rewards on some external validation to measure its value. So don't look to external validation for your goals or actions [Highlight: Solution point]. This means to stop announcing to the world [Highlight: Solution point] what you're going to do, and just do it instead. There are no amount of likes, replies and retweets that will move you forward in your goal. Those are just vanity metrics [Comment : Explore vanity metrics in more detail] that keep you distracted, but when it's all said and done, hold very little value. Get no engagement and you feel deflated. Get too much engagement and you feel overwhelmed that you've taken on more than you can chew. [Comment : Interesting balance between too little and too much] FLEETING NOTES BY EXAMPLE 104 The real benefits come from intrinsic rewards [Highlight: Key point]. Focus more on the mastery of your craft [Highlight: Solution point]. If you want to write, focus on the skill of communicating efficiently and elegantly. Only compare yourself to your previous self and never to anyone else. Schedule your actions [Highlight: Key solution point] It is one thing to create a plan of what to do, but it is more useful creating a plan of when to do it [Comment : Not to do lists, but do lists with a specific date]. We often abandon goals under the excuse of not having enough time. But yet while we are all given the same 24 hours a day, why is it that some achieve more than others? It's not that we don't have enough time, it's that we never allocated our time to actions we need to take [Comment : We just never made it a priority and never scheduled it in. This might be the root ah-ha point of the article]. Simply scheduling time doesn't mean we'll do it. Be realistic and start with just 5 minutes of time scheduled [Comment : What does this really mean? Is it that we should commit to just 5 minutes of action?]. A schedule creates a routine, and a routine is formed from habits [Highlight: Key solution point]. Get into the habit of just turning up [Highlight: Key solution point]. Build on incremental habits We must start small [Highlight: Solution point], and I mean very — almost boringly small. For example, start with writing for 5 minutes per day, every day. Something that we can still do when the motivation fades and the willpower is gone [Comment : What’s the relationship between motivation and willpower?]. Writing for 5 minutes will not impact anything in our lives. We can take a special intrinsic satisfaction in doing it consistently and must protect the activity like we need to protect our ability to breathe. Only when we are comfortable to trust that we can turn up every single day for 5 minutes, then we can start to expand on your actions. Get into the flow of doing the actions that will achieve our FLEETING NOTES BY EXAMPLE 105 goal so that it's frictionless to turn those 5 minutes into 10, 20 and even 60 minutes at a time [Comment : Only after building the habit should we increase the difficulty]. We will benefit from the compound effect of all these small habits. Remove friction [Highlight: Key solution point] Our physical environment can be a significant hindrance to achieve a state of flow [Highlight: Key benefit]. Imagine that during the course of a day we have a set of willpower coins. The moment something interrupts your flow — an untidy desk, a friend who dumped their daily crap on you, an unexpected telesales phone call or no milk in the fridge — we spend a willpower coin [Comment : Key concept of having willpower coins that we spend]. By the end of the day, we will have used most, if not all of our coins. We must avoid spending our willpower coins by optimising our physical, social and spiritual environment [Highlight: Key solution point]. Clear our space, plan our meals, turn off our phones, be mindful to avoid negative conversations and meditate to clear our mind of daily stresses. With practice, we'll be able to enter a state of flow when we carry out the actions for your goals. Be committed [Highlight: Key solution point] — deeply committed We often have an image of ourselves that we wish we were. We may wish we could play the guitar, look athletic or write a book. The list is almost endless and with a spark of motivation we may set our sights on these goals. The truth however is a little more harsh than we'd like to admit. More often than not, we don't really want these things. We are interested in them, but we're not committed. [Comment : How do we know if we really want it or just like the idea of it?] This means we won't give up our daily comforts and introduce new stresses and pains to get it [Comment : “The draw of familiarity is greater than the pull of change”]. We don't obsess FLEETING NOTES BY EXAMPLE 106 and strive to push for every waking moment to seek it. We simply just weren't that interested. In order to succeed we need to pick our primary calling of what we are prepared to sacrifice our comforts for [Comment : Are we over optimistic that it won't take sacrifice? Are we scared to sacrifice, maybe because it lets someone else down? Do we downplay the need to do it?]. Everything else is secondary and we should avoid spending energy on these and focus on our one true goal. Sometimes we may not know what that true goal is. That's actually okay. Using incremental habits [Comment : We don’t always know what we want, but we can focus on gaining skills and let the passion find us later] to keep turning up and develop our mastery, we can turn one of our interests into something we are committed to. Experts often only become masters in their craft after years of turning up and doing the work, and not because they were passionate about it. Once we find our true goal, we must remove the noise that is distracting us. We need to be okay with letting go [Comment : This is a subtle point. What does it actually mean to ‘let go’ and is this a hard thing to do in reality?] so that we can focus our energy on the actions that will help us succeed. Motioning if left unchecked means we continue a cycle of being dreamers who are perpetually waiting for something external to make our dream happen [Comment : We might be observing this in others. Do I do this?]. By observing this we can recognise it and mitigate the negative effects. We can focus on small habits that allow us to develop grit so we stick through it when motivation and willpower are at an all time low. LITERATURE NOTES BY EXAMPLE Motioning Motioning is where we feel progress towards a goal but take no action. See Also: 1. [[Motioning triggered by our brain]] Motioning triggered by our brain This can be triggered by our brain receiving a dopamine hit from us performing the intent of carrying out a desired action, but without actually acting on it. For example, sharing our intent on social media and garnering likes can be enough to feel good about it, giving our brain a signal that we have accomplished something, when in fact, we haven’t. This can reduce the desire to carry out any further actions. Failure to acknowledge motioning We may fail to admit that we are in a state of motioning because it may trigger a sense of guilt or embarrassment. Our social credibility is on the line if we have shared publicly what we will be achieving. One trait that may follow to avoid embarrassment is to find a new project to announce that sounds like you’re marking further progress, but you’re masking the previous failures. 110 LITERATURE NOTES BY EXAMPLE Vanity metrics We may often seek vanity metrics, such as likes on social media. These give us a sense of progress and success, especially when in relation to a project we are talking about. The downside is that the metrics have no bearing on our ability to deliver the project. If we receive little engagement, then our self esteem is negatively impacted because it comes across as a failure or unworthy project. If we receive a lot of support from others, then it can become overwhelming and a sense of imposter syndrome can creep in. How to avoid motioning To avoid motioning you want to avoid [[Vanity metrics]] so that [[Motioning triggered by our brain]] doesn’t happen. Create a plan of the actions needed to act on the goal. These can include: 1. [[Incremental habits]] 2. [[Do dates instead of due dates]] 3. [[Remove friction]] 4. [[Be committed]] Incremental habits These are small habits that can be started that gradually increase in intensity. The goal is to build the habit of doing the task initially, not that the task is done well. Only once the habit to perform the task is established, can the intensity of the task be increased. Without habits you will default into your old routine as this is the path of least resistance. “The draw of familiarity is greater than the pull of change” 111 LITERATURE NOTES BY EXAMPLE Motivation vs willpower Motivation happens when you act on a task when you are in the mood. This may happen at the start of an exciting project. Willpower is what will get you to act on the task when you are not in the mood. The problem with both is that if you lack both motivation and willpower, there is little chance that you will act on the task. To overcome this, build [[Incremental habits]] to reduce the effort required to perform the task. Do dates instead of due dates When creating a task list, instead of allocating when the item is due, put the date that you will work on the item. This means everything can be scheduled and isn’t left to chance of being completed in time. Remove friction In order to help get into the flow of a task, you want to remove as much friction as possible that can slow you down. This can include ensuring that your workspace is kept clean and tidy. Avoid things that can cause interrupts, such as notifications on your smartphone. Be mindful of the people who influence your mood, particularly if they tend to give you their problems. 112 You’ll observe that I have used some internal links between the notes. This is useful to group the ideas together so they are easy to discover and explore when reviewing the notes. LITERATURE NOTES BY EXAMPLE Be committed Often we make goals on projects that interest us. But when it comes down to it, we aren’t prepared to make any sacrifices that would enable us to commit to the project. We fail to question what comforts we currently have that we would be prepared to give up. Similarly, we often fail to ask what pain we’re prepared to introduce in order to truly achieve the goal. If we are unable to find items that we are not committed to, then we need to look at what skills we wish to develop instead. If you don’t know what you’re passionate about, then focus on the skills to gain which can be utilised in many ways. Permanent notes by example The goal of creating your permanent notes is to take your understanding from your literature notes and consider it holistically across your entire slip box. For this example, we’re going to use the book Atomic Habits by James Clear. To help set the scene, we’ll base this on a set of literature notes from the book using the techniques described previously. Within the slip box, there are permanent notes that already exist, and were populated from the book Mindset by Carol Dweck. PERMANENT NOTES BY EXAMPLE 114 Our objective is as follows: 1. Consider each literature note from the Atomic Habits book and make sure you understand them. 2. Consider where they sit within the collection of permanent notes. a. Are there any existing notes that talk about the same thing? b. Are there any existing notes that are useful to link to as their concepts are related? c. Do you have any original ideas as you go through the process of converting them? d. What Maps of Content would the new permanent notes best fit within. 3. Create a new permanent note or update an existing one. Ask questions to your Zettelkasten by example One thing we often talk about when it comes to the Zettelkasten, is being able to ask it questions. Sounds weird right? ASK QUESTIONS TO YOUR ZETTELKASTEN BY EXAMPLE 131 Asking the right questions It is important to know how to ask the right questions. You can ask simple questions, like “What was the formula to calculate the area of a circle?”. You might have a note with the answer, and it would be simple to answer. Other questions might be “What is the difference between … and …?” By comparing things by phrasing it as a question, you can answer them more precisely. An example might be “What is the difference between a solopreneur and a bootstrapper?” You might have notes about single founder businesses, and you might have notes about founders bootstrapping their business without external funding. But you haven’t directly compared the two. Now you have the opportunity to do so. But the most interesting questions are the ones that are almost impossible to answer. The ‘bigger than you’ type of questions. The type of questions that can spark a lifetime of curiosity and research. You can obviously come up with any number of questions. To keep this simple, focus on questions that: • Align with your goals—They should align with the goals of why you’re doing such research. Without this alignment, it can be a bit academic to be aiming for something that you don’t really know why you’re doing it. • Are of deep interest to you—You want to be interested in the research. Answering questions where your heart just isn’t in it can become unenjoyable. • Allow you to scan for opportunities—You want your questions to be something to consider as you discover new information. Like trying to fit a geometric shape into a box with holes, you want to see if any new information fits an open question you have. ASK QUESTIONS TO YOUR ZETTELKASTEN BY EXAMPLE 132 • Can be answered gradually—You should be able to break down difficult questions into smaller, simpler questions that can be answered. Over time you’ll add pieces to the larger puzzle. In some cases, new research might not give you an answer, but a better question to ask. Let’s look at an example. On a personal level, I have my own ‘why’—you know, the thing that drives my motivation and focus. It is “To inspire a generation of thinkers and doers”. What I like to do is break this down into a set of questions. WRITING A BLOG ARTICLE BY EXAMPLE PART 4 ADVANCED ZETTELKASTEN 141 Creating fleeting notes How you create your fleeting notes can be a very individual thing. As we read a book, our mind will interpret it based on the things that are important to us. Your previous understanding and general comprehension will have an influence. You can never step into the same book twice, because you are different each time you read it—John Barton You may revisit the same material in the future and look at it with a completely different perspective. For example, learning about entrepreneurship when you’re creating your first startup is very different to learning about it when you are raising capital and managing a team of fifty people. There is no standard way to create fleeting notes, and if you're a beginner in your Zettelkasten journey, it can be really hard to know where to start. When you’re new to a topic, you may find yourself highlighting lots of passages and trying to capture as much of the information as possible. The problem arises when you look away from the material. You can’t recall it. It’s like the information evaporates. But read it again, and it all comes flooding back. This is where you experience recognition of the material, but are unable to recall it. When you’re in this situation, you are more of a passive reader. It means you can’t really make judgements about what to make notes on and what to leave out. Everything feels important. But as you gain a deeper understanding of the material, you will be familiar with the concepts and the patterns. So what you highlight from the material might be just the small nuggets that you feel are useful. These may be elements that you want to refer to in your own writing. It might support your line of thinking, or it might counteract it. CREATING FLEETING NOTES 142 Other times you may highlight a piece of text is when it sparks a tangential thought. You capture it as it may connect with something else that you’ve been ruminating about. These are great opportunities to make a personal note on what the passage means to you. To give you a starting point, here’s how you can approach your fleeting notes: 1. Capture for learning—Highlight or quote text that is a useful reference. It is a key point that will aid your ability to recall the information when you write literature notes. 2. Talk to the author—When you read, you’re really having a conversation with the author. The author is making a point, and you have an opportunity to respond in your notes. Ask questions, call them out, agree or disagree, spot what they’ve missed or simply celebrate the profoundness or subtleties of their ideas. 3. Tangential ideas—Let your mind wander and see where it goes. If the material sparks an idea, capture it and make a note of what you’re thinking. Write what sparked the idea, what the idea is and what you should do to explore it further. 4. Action points—Sometimes what you read really feels like you need to hear it. You need to take action. Capture this. Add a hashtag #action so you can find these easier and make it a priority. 5. Analogies—Humans are great at finding patterns and what we read is no exception. If what you read is analogous to something you’re familiar with or a problem you’re trying to solve, then make this connection. This is where the beauty of connecting ideas really shines. It helps your understanding and amplifies your thinking. 6. Visual references—Sometimes a diagram or picture explains what needs to be understood clearly. Capture this. If you’re using a computer, screenshot it and paste it into your notes. If you’re reading a physical book, highlight the images. Sequencing your notes Since one of the core themes of the Zettelkasten is to have your notes written atomically, it raises a very simple problem. What if the topic needs to span multiple notes? There are multiple considerations that arise when it comes to numbering your notes. Firstly, in a digital system, you don’t actually need to number them. The filename of each note can be the reference and you can easily search for it. This does introduce a problem however. What if you change the name of a file? Should the software automatically update every reference to it? That’s when the question of numbering comes up. How do you number your notes, and what does it even mean to number them? The Folgezettel system The Folgezettel system refers to a manual numbering system that allows you to increment from one note to the next, but also insert notes at any point and not have to renumber each note in the sequence to fit it in. If you look up the Folgezettel system online, you’ll find that the topic talks about what it means, whether Niklas Lumnan used it, and how it applies in a digital sense. SEQUENCING YOUR NOTES 166 Personally, I consider this semantics. I want to understand the purpose of a numbering system and whether it is useful in my own note-taking. At its core, it’s basically an alternating system between letters and numbers. Increment the numbers to represent the next note in the sequence. Add a letter when you want to branch. For example, I may have a sequence of notes about Logical Fallacies. 100 Ad Hominem 101 Appeal to Common Belief 102 Appeal to Emotion 103 Appeal to Law 104 Argument from Offence Now what if I want to insert a note about `Emotional Blackmail` at the 102 point to speak about the ‘Appeal to Emotion’, but not break the flow of notes in the sequence. I can insert a child note as such: 102a1 — now I have a new subsequence which can continue its own thread of notes by using 102a2, 102a3, 102a4, etc. 100 Ad Hominem 101 Appeal to Common Belief 102 Appeal to Emotion 102a1 Emotional Blackmail 103 Appeal to Law 104 Argument from Offence If I want to create a separate subsequence, I can use 102b1. For example: 100 Ad Hominem 101 Appeal to Common Belief SEQUENCING YOUR NOTES 167 102 Appeal to Emotion 102a1 Emotional Blackmail 102a2 When emotional blackmail backfires 102b1 Examples of Appeal to Emotion 102b2 Appeal to Emotion used in Politics 103 Appeal to Law 104 Argument from Offence With this notation, it’s possible to create a full, ever growing tree of notes without ever having to rewrite a single unique identifier. Limitations of the Folgezettel system One challenge that has arisen with the Folgezettel system is what do you do if you want to insert a note at the beginning. This is problematic because you can only branch off an existing note, but you cannot branch before. This is also true for any branch. You cannot insert a note at the top of an existing branch. I don’t claim to know the answer here. It’s a neat system for being able to have immutable numbers for your notes in a physical system. Within a digital note-taking system however, the need for such a numbering system is less relevant as you have the ability to find and link notes by almost any dimension. This could be a text search, use of hashtags, follow links and many more. This is not practical in an analogue note-taking system. Datetime system An alternative approach would be to use a timestamp in the format of YYYYMMDDHHMMSS. For example: 202302141030—representing 10:30am on 14th February 2023. SEQUENCING YOUR NOTES 168 This really only achieves two things. The first is that every note can have a unique identifier without clashing. The second is that you can use it to sort the notes based on the time of creation. The greater the number, the more recent it is. But that’s about it. It doesn’t help us string notes together in a sequence or express the relationship between a note and the sub threads of ideas. It merely serves as a purpose to link to a note by an identifier in a piece of software, and not much more. Choosing the right numbering system While there will undoubtedly be more ways to number your notes, I would prefer to opt for a system like the Folgezettel. It only solves the problem of having unique note identifiers along with thinking of your ideas in threads of thoughts. This can be very helpful to ensure they remain unchanging across the multiple notes. The added benefit of the Folgezettel system is that you can easily apply it to an analogue Zettelkasten. Don’t feel that you do need to implement a numbering system. You can use the note title as the unique identifier and Maps of Content to sequence the notes in a hierarchical structure. Organising the chaos The idea of putting all your notes in a single slip box can be quite daunting. As humans we like to categorise things so that we can keep them neatly organised. We like to name things, as demonstrated by nouns making up a significant portion of any language. The problem with everything being placed in a single dumping ground is that you can’t find what you need when you need it. You also don’t know if you’re adding something that has already been mentioned. This can lead to multiple versions of the same idea and your slip box becomes a ‘write only’ place where you don’t look back at previous notes. We need a method to organise the chaos. Here are a few approaches that can help. 1. Having a consistent naming convention—This is helpful so you know what the pattern is to locate existing notes. 2. Use index notes—Notes such as a Map of Content can be useful to outline which notes relate to which themes. 3. Use tags—Tags can provide auxiliary information that can be useful for locating notes around a given theme. Although tags can be less useful than having an organised set of index notes, you either have lots of notes unorganised within a tag, or you create too many tags to choose from—just like having rigid folders. If carried out successfully, your slip box should be able to handle tens of thousands of notes. ORGANISING THE CHAOS 177 Thinking like a database A useful technique is to think of your slip box like a database of notes, not a folder storing a finite collection of notes. A database allows you to query its contents via a number of different methods. You can query by date, by relationships, by title, etc. You can create index notes that list specific permanent notes based on a given query. For example, you could have an index note showing all the notes you have around Psychology. Or you might have an index note for all the notes with a hashtag status of #status/draft. The flexibility you have can be down to the note-taking software you use. Software like Obsidian gives you the ability to use third party plugins like the Dataview plugin. This allows you to embed a table block within a note and list all the matching notes based on a query. This is a great way to think of your notes as a database and it automatically updates when you add or modify any of the notes in your slip box. Storing your index notes You want to make your index notes easy to find within your slip box. This can be achieved by storing them in a separate folder or by tagging them with a hashtag as index notes. You can also create an index note that lists all the other index notes if you want to collate them into one entry point to your Zettelkasten. One such example of this would be introducing a topic such as Business, which contains sub-index notes like Finance, Leadership, Product Development and Marketing. Each of those child index notes would then list the permanent notes directly, or could in turn be another index note. For example, Marketing might link to Inbound, Sales, Paid Advertising and Social Media. Any of these could be their own index notes. This is so you have the full hierarchy of your note system accounted for. This might be useful, but I wouldn’t stress if a note doesn’t naturally fit any of your index notes. Just make sure that it is linked to other permanent notes so that it doesn’t become lost.
