No doubt there will be endless examples where teams need to collaborate with common thinking and produce some form of output that can be used internally or directly with customers. At present, it is usually an individual who is responsible for managing their research and thinking. They work in isolation to produce a near finished document before they seek feedback from the team. When a new team member wants to contribute, they often start from zero. Software companies have gotten really good at sharing source code with very large teams, so much so that new team members can contribute with relative ease. But there is no established pattern for knowledge sharing within teams. The challenges with a team Zettelkasten Attempting to implement a Zettelkasten within a team will have a variety of challenges. Let’s explore what they may be. • Agreement on tooling—People like what they personally are familiar with. It can be hard to get adoption for new software within a team if the workflows are fundamentally different to what individuals are used to. You may need to get buy-in across the team, especially if the software requires a per user fee. • Consistent approach—Rarely are we taught how to use the tools. Everyone has a slightly different way of thinking and method of organising things. A collaborative Zettelkasten will need some ground rules in order to help everyone work A SHARED ZETTELKASTEN WITHIN A TEAM 180 effectively. You’ll need to think about who the champion is for setting these rules as rarely will it happen without some coordination. • Conflicting opinions—As you store notes in a collaborative Zettelkasten, different people on your team might have differing opinions on the topic. New processes might be needed on top of the Zettelkasten to allow for these to be resolved via some consensus. • Awareness of notes—You tend to favour things that you are familiar with. The notes you write personally will have more significance than a note written by someone else. It can be hard to make use of it as you will need to resort to doing some level of research on the notes made by your team members. • Too wiki-like—There is a real risk that there will be too much noise in the notes where too much is linked or is hard to find. If you’ve ever worked in a large organisation where information is stored on the Intranet or Wiki, then you will quickly realise that it’s easy to lose information hidden in the depths. • Notes become outdated—Similar to a knowledge portal or wiki within a company, it’s easy to put effort in creating new notes while they are relevant, but little motivation is there to go back and revisit existing notes to update or remove them. This means they can easily become outdated which weakens the trust the team has with the system. • Authority to make changes—When a note needs to be updated or removed, it can be hard to make a decision if someone else wrote the note. You may feel like you’re treading on their toes and may fear the repercussions if you make a mistake. • Autonomy in your thinking—You like to have autonomy in your thinking. Creating notes collaboratively might limit the freedom to express your ideas. You’ll be too conscious about whether a colleague will agree or disagree, or find it difficult to A SHARED ZETTELKASTEN WITHIN A TEAM 181 grasp. What you write in your private notes may be the seedling of a profound idea that you’re too cautious to say in a group. • Risk of not being simple—One goal of the Zettelkasten is to write simply so that it’s easy to comprehend later. This is fine on an individual level as you know if you understand. However, what one person understands, another may not. It can become hard to have the discipline from every team member to write simply so that everyone can understand it. As you can see, creating a collaborative Zettelkasten is an extremely problematic challenge. You need to have a trusting team, clear ownership, and courage to express your ideas out in the open for all to see. But if you achieve it, it can mean that knowledge can be utilised in a very effective way. New ideas can be explored collectively and the volume of work that can be published can increase exponentially. Whoever cracks it could reap great rewards. The alternative to a shared Zettelkasten If having a collaborative Zettelkasten is too daunting, then encouraging individual team members to manage their own can be the way to go. With effective coordination, each member represents and owns their contribution to collaborative projects. For example, if you’re writing a publication about the effects of sleep and learning, you may have one team member who has heavily researched sleep and another who has researched learning. They can collaborate and pull the insights together which can become the basis for a collaborative publication. This may be a more effective way of utilising the Zettelkasten within a team. It will lose some fidelity by not being able to connect ideas across disciplines, but with clever workshops and collaboration, those ideas could be connected in a form of ‘pair note-taking’. A SHARED ZETTELKASTEN WITHIN A TEAM 182 As always, you need to consider the longevity of the system. What happens when a team member leaves, do they donate their notes or take it with them? How do you stop two people researching the same thing, or should you actively encourage it? The discipline of parallel workflows A non-obvious benefit of the Zettelkasten is that you end up working on multiple ideas in parallel. Let’s say you want to write for your blog. A traditional way of approaching your workflow might look like this: 1. Ideate on the blog posts you wish to create 2. Maybe do some keyword research, but unlikely for a personal blog 3. Start with the blog title 4. Write your first draft 5. Add any graphics 6. Edit your draft 7. Publish This is what we would refer to as a top down approach. You start at the top (the topic) and keep adding detail as you go down to the foundations (the ideas). You may find gaps in your knowledge, so you carry out new research. What is key to this approach is that you’re unlikely to start 10 blog posts simultaneously. It would be quite tiresome to do lots of work up front, and then publish them all at the end. So instead, you do them one by one. Ali Abdaal refers to this in his Part Time YouTuber THE DISCIPLINE OF PARALLEL WORKFLOWS 183 Academy (PTYA) course as “don’t do heavy lifts”. In other words, don’t go through a lot of pain one article at a time. With the Zettelkasten, you adopt a bottom up approach. You start by researching and gathering information and ideas. You allow your interests to guide where this goes. As time goes on, your Zettelkasten has many different ideas and insights forming. At any point, you can decide whether your ideas have gained enough clarity that you feel it’s ready for sharing on your blog. In this way, your new workflow may look like the following: 1. Spend 30 minutes reading and making fleeting notes 2. Spend 30 minutes turning any completed fleeting notes into literature notes 3. Spend 30-60 minutes processing your completed literature notes into permanent notes 4. Spend 30 minutes exploring your permanent notes and making new connections. Ask questions or modify notes based on your latest thinking. Try to identify if any ideas you have are candidates for a publication. 5. Spend 20 minutes assembling your notes for any publication projects into the project outline 6. Spend 30-60 minutes using these notes to write your first draft 7. Spend 30 minutes editing existing drafts Depending on how much time you have, you may only do one of these activities a day. And how long you spend on them can vary to your preferences. THE DISCIPLINE OF PARALLEL WORKFLOWS 184 It’s important to understand that in a single week you might be creating fleeting notes about psychology, making literature notes on business, and writing a blog post about education. You’re working on different things in parallel. Each topic is just at a different stage of the workflow. This sounds like a lot, but it’s really about breaking down the activities into separate workflows where they’re not dependent on each other. They are simply multiple queues containing the backlog of things to process. The health of your Zettelkasten You have multiple queues to show the backlog of reading, fleeting notes to process, literature notes to process and the projects to work on. A healthy Zettelkasten removes the bottlenecks where one queue dries up or another gets too full. One common situation is having lots of fleeting notes being created, but they end up sitting there waiting to be converted to literature notes. This then makes it impossible to consistently add to your permanent notes because there is a bottleneck further up the workflow. Building a healthy Zettelkasten Visualising the health of your Zettelkasten is a tricky thing to do. It’s such an abstract thought that no existing software really has a method of effectively helping you build the right habits in the right place. This is what I want to change with Flowtelic, the note-taking app I’m building. I believe that a Zettelkasten should warn you if it’s becoming unhealthy. The application promotes a focus mode where you can easily see what’s in the backlog of each bucket and where the bottlenecks are. I get to observe some of the questions that come up. The following section is an exploration into the different questions that I have been asked. I want it to give you a different perspective to think about how to resolve some of the challenges you may face creating your own Zettelkasten. The answers I give may vary in approach to how I’ve explained it before. This is deliberate because I want you to understand the underlying ideas, not just the specific example. Atomic notes What if my notes are too long? As you make notes, it’s very easy to keep adding to them as you go, making them less atomic over time. To start with, you might actually be writing your fleeting notes. These could be the dumping ground of highlights, ideas or questions you have as you read a book or complete any course material. It’s okay for these notes to be long. They act simply as a way to capture the filtered information from the original material into something more manageable. However, as you process these into literature notes, you may find that making them atomic is still challenging. It’s now important to consider the atomic nature of these literature notes if you want to exploit the full benefit of them in your Zettelkasten. So when might you find your literature—and permanent notes— getting too long? Here’s are some examples: ATOMIC NOTES 188 • The notes explain a process—Take the biology topic of DNA replication where to explain it you need to encapsulate each stage of the process. It may be hard to break this into atomic components without it losing meaning. • Concepts that are highly interdependent—Sometimes the topic contains many higher interconnected concepts that it can be hard to untangle. It feels like that everything you mention requires a reference to something else. An example of this might be explaining how quantum computers work which relies heavily on foundational concepts and explanations. • Personal reflections—When you are reflecting on your own thoughts and experiences. It can be hard to break these down as the material might be so intertwined with events or a conversation along with your subjective reflections. • Historical facts—Listing out facts of a historical event can be quite difficult to break down as you would end up with lots of very isolated notes. An example could be explaining the events of the 1666 Great Fire of London. In these situations it can be tempting to keep your notes dense with information. However an alternative approach would be to consider it as a sequence of continuation notes—where one builds on the knowledge gained from the previous. For example, if you were to make notes on the steps of DNA replication, each atomic note might be only one step, but the notes are kept in a sequence. For example: 1. Replication Fork Formation a. Enzymes called helicases unwind and separate the two strands of DNA 2. Primer Binding ATOMIC NOTES 189 a. Another enzyme called Primase adds short RNA primers to the exposed single strands of DNA b. This provides a starting point for the replication process 3. Elongation a. The DNA polymerase enzymes move along each strand of DNA b. They add nucleotides to the growing new strand c. A, T, C or G is added at each position along the new chain 4. Proofreading a. As nucleotides are added, DNA polymerase enzymes check for errors and correct them if needed 5. Termination a. The process continues until the polymerase reaches the end of the DNA molecule b. It could encounter another obstacle such as a damaged section of DNA 6. Rejoining a. Ligase enzymes seal any gaps in the new DNA strands completing the replication process As you can see, we have a sequence of 6 notes explaining the complete process. By having these notes stored atomically, it now makes it easy to link to other notes that help elaborate on any parts of the process. For example, a note explaining how the error correction process works could be linked to the Proofreading note. Another example would be ideas about what causes DNA damage, where it can link to the termination process of DNA replication. ATOMIC NOTES 190 By keeping these atomic, it means you break down your understanding into the smallest possible parts. They become highly linkable within your overall system. Also, by keeping them as a sequence, you maintain the overall structure as though they were one longer note. Fleeting and literature notes Why bother with fleeting notes when reading a book? It’s easy to assume that the meaning of a literature note is simply the notes made from a piece of literature such as a book. I feel that you must first capture the raw, but filtered information from the book as fleeting notes. You use this when creating your literature notes. This method differs from others’ teaching around the Zettelkasten. There’s no specific right or wrong method. Feel free to adapt the approach so long as you understand what you’re adapting and the consequences of it. If you jump right to creating literature notes as you read a book, you may find that you later try to add it to your permanent notes too soon as you haven’t fully understood the material. You may have fleeting notes which could just be your own ideas from daily journaling. There’s no source material such as a book that they come from. These too would be converted to literature notes where you express those ideas in a more complete and atomic way. It gives you space to really think about those ideas and make sure you understand them. Another way to think about it is if you were to consider the role of fleeting notes and literature notes differently. You could consider a fleeting note like a ‘capture note’, and a literature note like an ‘understanding note’. FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 191 Only when you understand the notes are you ready to merge them into your permanent notes. What’s different about literature and permanent notes? When you’re new to creating your Zettelkasten, it can seem like your literature notes are no different to permanent notes. This is because you have no existing content within your slip box to merge them with. The most important distinction is as follows: • Literature notes—These are your atomic notes from one source material, such as a book. It’s to ensure you understand what the author was trying to say. They don’t need to be concerned with other books you’ve read, even if they contradict each other. Literature notes are locally scoped to the source material. • Permanent notes—These are the atomic notes from all the material you have thought about. They contain ideas from all the books you’ve read. The ideas within them are connected to each other so your understanding makes sense holistically. You have an opportunity to resolve conflicts where two authors disagree on a topic. They are globally scoped to all the material you’ve studied. Can’t I just write permanent notes? This is a common feeling when you’re creating a brand new Zettelkasten. Your first set of literature notes will most likely be placed with no modification into your slip box as permanent notes. Because of this, it can be tempting to convert your fleeting notes directly into your slip box as permanent notes. It can be hard to justify the effort required to do the intermediary work to create literature notes. FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 192 As your Zettelkasten starts to grow, I would strongly urge against the temptation to work directly in your permanent notes. Here are my reasons why this would be problematic: • You can’t batch your workflow—As your thinking gets complex, it can become more time consuming to focus on creating your atomic notes while simultaneously considering what existing permanent notes you have. You want these as separate processes so you can minimise the cognitive load by only doing one type of work at a time. You’re either understanding the source material, or you’re considering the impact of the new material to your existing thinking. Don’t do both at the same time. • Your thinking will be influenced by your previous ideas—The main purpose of creating literature notes is to make sure you fully comprehend the material you’re studying. If you’re working directly in your slip box, you may be limiting the perspective of which to consider any new ideas. This can result in you suffering confirmation bias and not being open to new ideas that challenge your existing thinking. • It can be hard to think simply—When learning anything new, you need to ensure that you fully understand it. This can be difficult for topics that are more abstract. The way to help you understand is to keep asking simple questions until you have the foundational knowledge to work from. This is easier to do within your literature notes because you’re not distracted by the volume of notes in your slip box. • You may jump to conclusions—If you have some knowledge of the subject in your slip box, you may be tempted to jump to conclusions and gloss over new information that could provide some interesting insights. • You may lose track of your thinking—For larger study material, it can be quite time consuming to go through them all in the detail you need. You may spread your effort over days or FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 193 weeks. If you’re adding your literature notes into your slip box as permanent notes as you go, you will find it hard to pick up from where you left off as they will now be merged in with your previous notes. There are of course some benefits to working directly in your permanent notes. These may be to save time, or to use the existing permanent notes as foundational information so you don’t have to repeat yourself. Just be mindful of the consequences of your approach and do what works best for you. How do I use daily notes with the Zettelkasten method? Daily notes are a great way for you to capture what’s top of mind each day. It helps you reflect on the successes and failures. It helps you reason about areas you are struggling with and helps you take a step back and consider things more holistically. It can also help you plan your day and give you an opportunity to create focus for your day. With a great template, you can use this as a prompt to unlock some hidden gems in your knowledge journey. Here are some examples: 1. What one thing you can do that will have the biggest impact?—Think of the goals you want to achieve. Now look at what you are currently working on and see which ones are most likely to help you move towards those goals. It’s easy to find yourself focusing on the wrong things. 2. What is making this hard?—Now think about the work you’re trying to accomplish. What is making it take longer than you expect? Try to find the blocking factors, such as lack of clarity, and see if you can think about it in a way that can unblock it. 3. What’s the simplest thing to start these tasks?—Look at what you have planned. What is the first action you can take that FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 194 will help you start gaining momentum on the task? Focus on the simplest things that can help you slip into flow. 4. What distractions might you have?—Now think about the things going on in your day that might distract you. Are you waiting for a phone call? Do you have a delivery? Can you prioritise shallow tasks around those times and keep your deep work activities protected. 5. What were my recent gains?—Celebrate what you did well. It’s important to remember how far you’re coming so you can feel positive about taking on new challenges for the day. 6. If you did just one thing, which would make you feel like you’ve won the day?—It’s easy to overestimate what you can achieve in a single day. Trying to do too much and not achieving it all can be demoralising. Take this as an opportunity to celebrate doing just one thing for the day and let everything else be a bonus. Maybe start with that one thing so you bank success for the day. 7. What ideas do you want to explore?—Take a moment to capture any top of mind inspiration and ideas that you want to get out of your working mind and into your system. This frees your mind to focus on one task at a time. These are just a few examples, but it can help illustrate where daily notes can be used as a tool to set you up for success. What you have is essentially a daily fleeting note. Use it as a way to focus on what to work on with your Zettelkasten that keeps things moving. Daily notes can help you build the habit of using your Zettelkasten in a consistent and effective way. Should you convert these daily fleeting notes to literature notes? Maybe? Use it as an opportunity to review them and make any FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 195 literature notes where you want to store those ideas in your permanent notes. What do I do about data tables and diagrams? Sometimes you find that what you’re studying has some really interesting data that you want to capture as a reference in the future. It can be hard to approach this in your mindset of writing atomic notes because it’s so densely packed with information. In this case, it’s perfectly fine to capture data tables and diagrams as a reference within your notes. You don’t want to feel like you have to recreate everything in your own words for it to enter your Zettelkasten. This would simply be a reference, which you can link your own thoughts to. For example, you might have some statistics on a topic where you have the results formatted in a table. Take a screenshot or copy the table contents in its own note. Then within your literature notes, reference it with your own thoughts around the data. Does it conclude with a specific point? Are there any issues with the data? How can it be used elsewhere in your thinking? Another example could be where you’re studying biology. Imagine you have a diagram explaining the inner workings of a human cell. You can copy the diagram and create your own notes around it to make sure you understand the diagram. You might want to recreate parts of the diagram, but only do that if you feel you have a way to present the information better for your understanding. Maybe it’s too complex and you can split it into simpler parts. The only word of warning here is when you come to creating your own original work out of your Zettelkasten. You want to be able to use as many of your notes as possible without having to do any heavy lifting to recreate it. If you’ve copied a diagram from another source, you might not be able to use it for anything you publish due to copyright. FLEETING AND LITERATURE NOTES 196 This is not an issue for studying, but can be problematic for any work you publish. In this case, you might need to spend some time creating your own original diagrams that you can include in your published work. Adding to your permanent notes Do all literature notes become a permanent note? When you create your atomic literature notes, you can visualise how it could be added to your slip box. After all, permanent notes are written in a very similar way where you write simply and link things together. So it might be tempting to try and make sure you put every single literature note in your slip box. Not doing so might feel like you’re creating waste in your note-taking. Consider your literature notes as your understanding of the source material in isolation. When you come to put them into your slip box as permanent notes you need to consider it in a different context— taking into account all the notes you have in your slip box. Here are a few reasons you might not put a literature note in your permanent notes. • It doesn’t add anything new—You might find that you have already come to the same understanding previously and adding a duplicate note doesn’t add anything new. An example of this might be a note explaining the purpose of DNA from a new text book, but you already covered that from a previous text book. • You might ultimately disagree with it—It’s okay to add notes that you disagree with, and add your reasoning. But every so often you will find content that once you scratch beneath the surface really has no substance. An example might be ideas that reinforce previously debunked theories, like an entrepreneurship author advocating for sleeping for four hours a night to hustle. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 197 Your existing research might conclude why this is not a good idea. In this case you may choose to omit the note in your slip box, or add it with a reference and your reasoning for why you disagree. • You can’t justify the claim—Sometimes you come across a note that sounds like it makes sense, but as you consider it in the full context of your permanent notes, you realise it just doesn’t hold up to scrutiny. One example may be your research on long term fasting and its effects on cancer reducing autophagy. You may find that you don’t know what research the information is based on. So you may choose to omit it for the time being, or add it with a note indicating that this doesn’t have references to justify the claim. • You don’t understand it—When you create your literature notes, you may find that it feels like it makes sense—enough for you to write your notes. But only on review do you start to notice that it doesn’t actually make sense. This can be because the source material glosses over the mechanics of how a concept really works and you’re not stuck trying to explain it in your Zettelkasten. If it’s not a critical part of your interests, you may choose to omit it altogether. Otherwise you may choose to add it as a question to prompt for more research in the future. • It’s too much of a tangent—You may discover something that feels important in the moment, but on reflection would take you in a direction you simply have no interest in. In this case you may choose to ignore it if you feel confident that you won’t want to explore it further, and if you did, you would probably do it from better sources anyway. Be careful not to only add notes that you agree with. This can result in confirmation bias. You might find you only consider information that aligns with your belief and don't truly allow yourself to think critically about the subject. This can be all too tempting. So be mindful about the reason why you’re choosing not to add the note as a permanent note. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 198 What if my permanent note is the same as my literature note? There are two ways to think about your knowledge system. The first is a point in time snapshot of your current thinking. Old notes are removed, understanding is updated and ideas are adapted. This however makes it difficult to see how you came to this understanding because you lose the historical journey that got you there. The second way to think about your knowledge system is like a version control system. You could theoretically go back in time and see what it looked like in the past. It’s no longer a snapshot, but a historical record. I mention this as you will now face the question of what happens to the literature notes as you transform them into permanent notes. Do you update the original literature note and call it a permanent note, or do you take a copy? The answer is down to personal preference, but here are some benefits of keeping your literature notes separate to your permanent notes. • Full audit trail—When you create your permanent notes, you can reference the literature note (or notes) that it was based on. Those literature notes in turn will have references to the original fleeting notes they were based on. And ideally the fleeting notes will reference the source material it was based on. This gives you a full audit trail of where your ideas originated. • Easier referencing—With such an audit trail, when you mention an idea in a new piece of work (such as an article you plan to publish), you have access to the original material you can reference. If the ideas were based on a study, this trail should take you back to the exact study in question. If it was based on a quote from a book, then you should be able to locate the original text, author, book and publish date. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 199 • Easier to revisit the literature—If you ever need to revisit the material your literature notes were made from, having access to the literature notes at the time you read the material helps you know what state your thinking was at. It helps you spot whether you misunderstood the material, especially if you find yourself re- reading the material or have been challenged to clarify your reasoning by someone else. There are however drawbacks to duplicating your literature notes into permanent notes. This can be the effort required to do so and the repetition of notes with very similar content in your slip box. Additionally, and depending on the software you use, you may find that your literature notes and permanent notes may have the same note titles. This can be confusing when searching for notes as both will appear in the search results. My recommendation is to archive literature notes when you have processed them. This still allows them to be linked to permanent notes, but doesn’t let them appear as ‘live’ notes when performing searches. This can be tricky depending on the software you use. Being able to see what your thinking was previously can be challenging for a lot of note-taking software. When you edit a note, it may not store the history of what it contained previously. This means the notes themselves only show your current thinking and not the journey that got you there. How important is this for you? That really comes down to personal preference. You’ll go a long way by updating notes and not worry about what they looked like in the past. Sometimes it’s nice to visualise how your thinking is evolving, but this is probably just a vanity and does not improve the quality of your thinking. Do I use one slip box for unrelated topics? There is a great benefit to keeping your notes in a single slip box. It means you can connect ideas together in novel ways that would otherwise have been missed. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 200 One such example might be looking at information theory and biology. If you are looking at how evolution replicates DNA, but also how information evolves in society, you might want to draw a connection between the two. After all, DNA is a form of information, but its physical nature has limitations, such as mutations and multiple parents producing an offspring. If you want to see what an example article of this concept would look like, then check out https://meda.io/evolve-your-thinking/. By having these as separate slip boxes, it means you are unable to create connecting ideas between the two concepts. You might be tempted to say that you could link between slip boxes, but all you have really achieved there is some categorisation by topic and you might as well go back to storing your notes in folders again. The true power of the Zettelkasten is to be able to connect disparate ideas together. As another example, imagine you are creating notes about The Golden Ratio. This is a mathematical ratio that keeps being found in nature and popularised in art due to it being aesthetically pleasing. Now imagine you’re making notes about social groups and the different relationships friends have within such groups. With both types of notes being present in your slip box, you can start to ask questions that would otherwise be nonsensical. Such a question might be, “Is there a relationship between the depth of your friendship network and the golden ratio?”. You may then create question notes which you can start to explore further. For example: “What are the structural properties of a social network?” “Does clustering within social networks have a correlation to the golden ratio?” “How to visualise the proximity and depth of a social graph?” ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 201 Okay, this is a contrived example and probably has no tangible meaning—notability because none of these topics are within my area of expertise. But what it highlights is that you can start to connect ideas together in such a way that new and interesting insights can now be possible. As you work with your Zettelkasten, you’ll have a ‘feel’ for the hunches you have about your ideas. That will guide what you decide to connect together and explore whether it reveals an insight—or simply leads to a dead end. There are however some examples where you may choose to have multiple slip boxes. These are: • Where the fields simply don’t overlap—One good example might be a programming slip box and a non-programming slip box. Notes about how to write HTML and what foods help you sleep better might be a bit of a stretch to connect together. But if you feel there’s a valid reason, then go have some fun mixing the ideas. • Where you don’t own the content—Having a personal slip box for your own thinking is great. However, if you want to apply this to your employment, it might be wise to separate the two. This is purely down to legal ownership of the work. • Where you’re collaborating—If you do work on a shared slip box with other people, then having it separate from your own personal one is a good idea. After all, you might not want someone else editing your carefully crafted notes. Personally, I have my main second brain slip box which contains all my non-fiction learning, ideas and what I would consider my main body of research. Alongside that I have technical slip boxes, one for programming and another for learning Blender 3D. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 202 How do you name your notes? As humans we love to name things. Pretty much everything we interact with has a name. However, the art of naming things can be very challenging—especially when it comes to our note-taking. When thinking about naming your notes, you can choose any method really. But here are a couple of suggestions. 1. Archivist—Do you write your note titles as though they have been categorised? For example “Mindset in Enterprise” or “Cell Division”. 2. Conversational—Do you give your notes a more conversational name, like how you would mention it mid sentence? For example “Company’s approach to mindset” or “How cells divide”. Of course, you can do what feels right for you. You might even want to mix the conventions you use. Where it gets interesting is how you use these when linking from within the contents of a note. If I’m using conversational titles, I may wish to add the link in a sentence, for example: “If you’re a business owner, you want to consider [[how companies approach mindset within a team]]” If you want to use the archivist approach, then you might list the links later in the note, for example: See Also: 1. [[Mindset in Enterprise]] Depending on the software you use to make the links, you can rewrite the title of a link. For example: “If you’re a business owner, you want to consider [[Mindset in Enterprise|how companies approach mindset within a team]]” ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 203 Within Obsidian you can use the pipe character to display the link more conversationally. What if two notes have the same name? I know what you’re thinking. If all your notes go in a single massive folder, you could potentially be adding thousands of notes into that folder. Then at some point, you discover that two notes have the same name but mean different things. An example of this could be the note “Obsidian”. It could refer to both Obsidian, the glasslike rock, or Obsidian, the note-taking app. But we have an even better example to reflect on. Wikipedia. All web pages on Wikipedia sit under the base URL https://en. wikipedia.org/wiki/. So, if I have the topic Mindset, this would be found under: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset But, the phrase Mindset could also mean the following: 1. The book Mindset by Carol Dweck 2. The 1984 computer called Mindset 3. The plug-in hybrid car called Mindset 4. The Mindset music album The way that Wikipedia solves this is by having a page referring to the disambiguous meaning of Mindset which lists all the different types of Mindset. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset_(disambiguation) It then means that each variation will have the topic put into the name of the page. 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset_(book) ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 204 2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset_(computer) 3. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset_(vehicle) 4. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mindset_(album) Wikipedia solves this issue by putting the topic as a suffix within the filename of the web page and placing it in brackets. We can apply the same approach to our note-taking and use a suffix notation to indicate the topic. I know it’s tempting to avoid this and place those notes within folders representing the topic. Doing so simply increases the cognitive load when trying to decide which folder a new note should be placed. It also doesn’t solve the issue of a note belonging to multiple topics. In conclusion, if you have two notes with the same name, then one or both need to be renamed to provide additional information to indicate which topic the note relates to. Personally, I consider this to be more of a limitation of the software than a limitation of the Zettelkasten. Let me explain. I like to think of all my notes like entries in a database. There could be one note, ten notes, or literally hundreds of thousands. It’s the metadata that gives it context. This metadata could be related to the theme or topic. I believe as long as note-taking uses a filesystem as its primary key (i.e. the filename), then these clashes will happen from time to time. It makes me wonder what a system would look like if your notes were simply a database of notes, but with the tools to easily visualise and prioritise the topic it refers to. ADDING TO YOUR PERMANENT NOTES 205 Referencing How do you give credit to the original speaker or author? As you read material such as books, you might want to cite a section from the book or credit the author as the source of your understanding. I like to do the following: 1. Create the person note—Add a note with the hashtag #person to indicate that it relates to an author. Briefly enter some memorable information about the person. For example, the person James Clear would have the contents “Author of [[Atomic Habits]]” 2. Create the book note—Add a note for the book, for example Atomic Habits with the contents “Written by [[James Clear]]”. 3. Reference the book in my fleeting note—I can now make a reference to the book in my fleeting notes. Ideally this will include a page number, or a timestamp. 4. Reference the fleeting note in my literature note—When I create literature notes from my fleeting notes, I can reference the specific line within my fleeting note that the atomic ideas are based on. 5. Reference my literature note from my permanent note— When creating my permanent notes, I like to reference back to the literature notes that they were inspired by. So whether I'm using a quote or capturing the author's viewpoint, I should be able to follow the references all the way back to the book and author to know who said it, where they said it and what they said. This is great when creating your own published work where you base it on your permanent notes. By following your references you’ll be able to cite the origins of those ideas. REFERENCING 206 In some cases, you might just have your own inspiration when reading. There’s no harm in creating an “Inspired by” reference back to the fleeting note. With all this set up, you can then look at an author, book, fleeting note, or literature note and see the backlinks to know where that note has been referenced and used in subsequent work. Maps of Content How many Maps of Content should I create? When you start to use Maps of Content within your Zettelkasten, you may find that they are mostly containing high level topics. For example, you might have one for Health, another for Economics and another for Business. But there is no reason why you can’t add additional perspectives on your notes through additional Maps of Content. It can then become a way to create unique slices of your notes based on what you find most interesting. This means a single note might appear in multiple Maps of Content. Here are some examples where you might create different types of Maps of Content. 1. By Theme—This is the most common. These can be the top level categories where you can outline the notes related to the theme inside. 2. By Idea—You might have an idea you want to explore. For example “Ways to challenge your own belief”. Here you can link to notes that you feel are relevant. 3. By Book—You might want to organise your notes based on the contents of a book. This can be very useful for textbooks where MAPS OF CONTENT 207 the contents start with foundational knowledge and then increases in complexity by building upon the information. 4. Glossary—You might want to create a glossary which can be organised alphabetically. This could be useful if you’re studying biology and want a glossary of Hormones within the human body. 5. By Questions—You might have open ended questions that you are seeking to answer. You can create a questions Map of Content which helps by linking to notes that might contribute to finding an answer. These are just some ideas and I’m sure you can come up with other types of Maps of Content that you can add to your Zettelkasten. Managing your notes When do you update existing notes? When we think of permanent notes, the name implies that they are forever and immutable. This suggests they are unchangeable and are set in stone. This is not the case. They are referred to as being permanent because it’s the final form which they will take to encapsulate your most current thinking on a given subject. So we need to consider when you would need to update a permanent note to be something different. Here are some scenarios: 1. A new literature note enhances your understanding— Here you would update the contents to contain your newer understanding. Sometimes it will be a better example or a better explanation. This is common for a newer Zettelkasten where you mention something, but later understand more about it. For example, you may have a note about the amygdala with the contents “The part of the brain that processes emotion”. Later you MANAGING YOUR NOTES 208 might study the amygdala directly and want to include information about its location within the brain. 2. You misinterpreted something—Sometimes you may find you get things wrong. Learning about a subject from different sources can help you understand it better. When reviewing your permanent notes you might find it wasn’t correct. 3. The permanent note contradicts your new literature notes—You may find that what you wrote originally contradicts what you’re now researching. One such example could be something like “There are health risks of the Keto diet with regards to high cholesterol”. Another book might go into more detail suggesting that the science is inconclusive. There will of course be other scenarios where you want to update your permanent notes. Make sure your references still make sense after making any changes. Depending on the software, you might find that you can keep a revision history of your notes. While it’s not obvious whether that would be useful, it does give some comfort knowing that you can peer back in time to recover any notes that you might have discarded but later found useful. If your software doesn’t do this, then there is no reason why you can’t create an archive folder, and move a copy of it there. Then you’re free to update the note while maintaining a historical copy. What happens to fleeting and literature notes? Depending on how strictly you follow the Zettelkasten workflow, you may find yourself with a collection of fleeting and literature notes that you no longer need. Once they have been processed and you have created your permanent notes, what purpose do they serve? MANAGING YOUR NOTES 209 I personally like to keep them and use them so I can reference them from my permanent notes all the way back to the original source material. But at the same time, I don’t want to clutter my Zettelkasten with notes that I don’t need to use on a day-to-day basis. This is where archiving can be a great option. Once they are done with, marking them as ‘complete’ or ‘archived’ in some way is a great way to remove them from view, but still access them when you want to look up your references. You can do this in your software via different methods. One would be to physically move the notes into an Archive folder which has a similar layout of sub folders to hold your fleeting and literature notes. Another option is to use some of the metadata capabilities of your note-taking software, such as using a hashtag like #status/complete. The software you use might even have an archive feature, but be mindful and make sure you can still link to them without having to move it out of the archive. Wont my notes get too messy without folders? It can certainly feel that your slip box is getting very messy as you add more and more notes into a single folder. The challenge this creates is that it takes longer to scan the list of files to find the one you’re looking for. If you like categorising things, you’ll be tempted to put them in sub folders by categories, but I would urge you to resist this temptation without really considering the long term effects. Finding notes across any number of folders or deciding where to create a new sub folder is a huge cognitive tax. You want to work fluidly with your note-taking. One of the main problems with some software applications is the perspective that your notes are physical files in a folder. If that perception was changed, then things would get a bit easier. MANAGING YOUR NOTES 210 This is why thinking of your collection of notes as entries in a database rather than a collection of files allows you to think of your notes as something you can query, not something you can manually look through. By having such a system in place, it means you can put hundreds of thousands of notes in your slip box without having to increase the complexity of how you interact with them. Then your Maps of Content, note metadata (tags, keywords, themes, etc), links to other notes and of course, full-text search are fantastic ways to recall the notes back out of your system. You can move from having to see them all in front of you to trusting you have a robust method of finding them by using the search functionality of your app. It is also important to know how to find notes that you already have. This helps you avoid scenarios where you create duplicate notes of the same thing because you didn’t remember that you had already written about the subject previously. This is especially true when you might phrase the name of the note slightly differently than you did before, but conceptually they are the same. An example would be a note “How to change your mindset” duplicating the contents of “Adopting a growth mindset”. These are ideas which I’m thinking about with Flowtelic. How can your notes be a robust database of your atomic ideas where you can surface and find them easily and at the right moment? How can you ensure that ideas aren’t lost and never seen again? I feel there is a lot of opportunity to discover better ways of working with a large collection of notes. Who has time to turn fleeting notes into literature notes? Time. The one thing we can all spend, but never replenish. It’s easy to fall into the trap of loving the idea of a full and healthy Zettelkasten, MANAGING YOUR NOTES 211 but end up with an imbalance of too many fleeting notes and note enough literature notes. You may also feel that the exercise of converting fleeting notes to literature notes—and then again into permanent notes—is too costly. When you embark on a knowledge journey there are literally endless avenues to explore, which would take many lifetimes to think deeply about them all. Really it comes down to priority. Use your time wisely. Think about what topics you really care about, and which ones are just useful. Spend more time on the things you are truly passionate about. But there are some workflow tips that can help you along the way. 1. Batch your workflow—Don’t try to do multiple things at the same time. So don’t try to create literature notes and permanent notes, and original thinking, and reading at the same time. Think of each type of activity as individual buckets and your job is to keep them moving consistently across the buckets. 2. Time box—With each distinct activity, implement small habits that allow you to chip away at each workflow bucket. For example, spend just 20 minutes converting fleeting to literature notes. Spend 30 minutes converting literature notes to permanent notes. 3. Look for imbalances—If you find that you have too many fleeting notes and not enough literature notes, then switch your focus to spending more time processing your fleeting notes into literature notes. A healthy Zettelkasten is where each bucket of notes has a stable and flowing amount of activity. 4. Make it fun—If you don’t enjoy it, you won't do it. Keep it fun. Think of it as a rewarding experience. Appreciate the activity of moving notes through the system, not necessarily that you’re creating amazing work at the end. It should become part of who you are, not just a thing you happen to do. MANAGING YOUR NOTES 212 5. Trust the process—Don’t give up too soon. Trust it. Commit to doing it properly for a period of time before making judgement. Like any new habit, it will take time to see the results of your hard work. What do you do with notes that are no longer relevant? As you create your collection of permanent notes, at some point you might think that a note is no longer relevant. Maybe this is because your viewpoint has significantly shifted, or it was in an area of work that you don’t need to think about any more. This can happen if you work in a very niche industry, but shift industry and know you won’t go back. Here are some options for you to consider: 1. Archive the note—As discussed previously, you can simply archive it. This means that it will be removed from view from your active notes. 2. Keep the note, but add a footnote—You may decide to keep it, but add to the note why you feel it is no longer relevant. This keeps your thinking current and avoids you somehow feeling it necessary to recreate it again in the future. 3. Consider the backlinks—The note might be linked from other notes in your slip box. Check if there are any backlinks and update those notes accordingly with your new thinking around the subject. What should I do with old versions of notes? This is an interesting question that comes up from time to time. What should you do with old versions of notes as you update them? I personally like to think of the bigger question: What is the scenario where I would need to look back at an older version of a note? MANAGING YOUR NOTES 213 This answer might vary for different people. If your notes are about things like public policy, then having a historical record of what changed and when it changed, might be more useful. But for most of us, I doubt this is the case. That said, here are some options you can consider: 1. Move the older contents to a change log—While your notes can be atomic, it doesn’t prevent you from storing historical information about it in the footnotes. Here you can document what changed, when it changed and why. 2. Archive a copy of the note—You can of course make a copy of the note and move the old version to an archive. You could adopt some type of version number for those copies so you can track them over time. 3. App level version history—Your note-taking app might internally track changes to your note anyway, which means you could time travel back to a previous version. 4. Use version control—Some people like to write their notes in text format like Markdown. This makes it excellent for storing your notes in a source control system like Git. While it is great for capturing the changes, it doesn’t help you understand the changes you make as you write your notes. If you find you are making updates to a note, just be mindful of any backlinks to the note and make sure they are still valid and relevant. When should I use hashtags? Hashtags are a great way to add metadata to your notes when working in a plain text format such as Markdown. Lots of note-taking apps support hashtags. Here are some use cases when you can use hashtags: MANAGING YOUR NOTES 214 • To track the status of a note—This can be very useful if you want to track the status of your notes. For example, it could be: #status/pending or #status/complete. You can then search for all pending notes using your software by matching the associated tag. Adding the forward slash also allows all ‘status’ hashtags to be grouped together in the user interface of your app. • To capture the theme—You can choose to use hashtags to signal that a note belongs to a specific theme. For example #mindset or #entrepreneurship. You can of course group these by a folder like #theme/mindset or #theme/entrepreneurship. • To capture actions—Sometimes in my fleeting notes I like to add #action next to a specific part of the note. This signals that I want to come back to this and take action based on the idea in the note. • To track questions—Adding a #question is also a great way to collate all your questions together and ensure they don’t get lost when buried within your notes. Feel free to experiment with workflows using hashtags in your Zettelkasten. Don’t be afraid to try different methods and reflect on what’s working and what’s not. Some software applications support first class properties for your notes which might make the need for hashtags redundant. Notion supports item properties and Obsidian supports front matter to store metadata. Hashtags are just a simple way to put metadata inside the body of a note. How do you store questions in your Zettelkasten? Being able to ask questions to your Zettelkasten is one of the powerful benefits that it provides. Rather than having a collection of static notes, you have a living and breathing form of your thinking. This means you can be dynamic with it, and asking questions is a great way to explore different ways of thinking. MANAGING YOUR NOTES 215 But how do you store these questions? What do they look like? In order to answer this, we first need to clarify what we mean by ‘a question’. A question may come in any of the following forms: 1. Fact-based questions—For example, you might ask “what is the average temperature of the human body?”. These types of questions are usually measurable and can be answered concretely. 2. Conceptual questions—You might want to ask questions about fundamental concepts or principles. For example, “How does mindset relate to mental health?”. 3. Clarification questions—This is where you want to strengthen your understanding, for example: “What’s a good example of a fixed mindset in a team?” 4. Cause and effect questions—This is where you try to understand how things affect each other. For example: “What causes a person to go from a growth mindset to a fixed mindset?” 5. Comparative questions—These questions involve comparing different ideas together to gain a deeper understanding. For example, “How does having a growth mindset compare with someone who has grit?” 6. Application questions—These questions try to identify ways to apply the knowledge learned to real world situations. For example: “How can a growth mindset be used to support your future leaders within a team?” 7. Evaluation questions—These questions help you critically analyse and evaluate the information. They may ask “What are the strengths and weaknesses?” or “How do we know this to be true?” 8. Synthesis questions—These questions help you think about the information or concepts more broadly to aid your MANAGING YOUR NOTES 216 comprehension. For example: “How can a growth mindset be used in education?” Depending on the questions, it might create one of the following actions: 1. To reason about your notes—A question might be answerable by working through your own understanding and ensuring that your ideas are clear and concise. For example, it might be to clarify what you mean with an example. 2. To search for factual answers—A question might require you to look up a fact or do more research in an area. For example, “How does the human cell work?”. 3. To scan for new insights—A question might not be easy to answer. It might be quite conceptual, but you want to bring it to the font of your mind when looking for new material to research. 4. To ask better questions—Some questions are just so abstract that they can’t really be answered. However, they may provide a good starting point to ask better questions which can be measured and tested. For example, “How can a growth mindset be used in education?” could be broken down into many sub questions, such as “What do educational institutes do to teach a growth mindset?”. For questions that can be answered, store the answer with the question in your permanent notes. For the questions that you don’t have an answer for, you can store these either within the notes they relate to, add a hashtag with something like #question so you can easily find them again. Another option is to append your questions to your Map of Content for the topic. These are the high level questions you want to keep evaluating if you have found any information that can help answer them. MANAGING YOUR NOTES 217 If you prefer, you can create a questions folder alongside your permanent notes folder, which simply holds the open questions as individual notes. As you create new permanent notes in the future, you can evaluate whether you have discovered the answer to the question. A good technique is to ask yourself ‘How will I find out the answer to this question?’. This might prompt for the books or articles that you need to add to your reading queue. There is no right or wrong technique, but I hope that you have an understanding that keeping track of your questions in your Zettelkasten is a great way to help you scan for anything that can be useful to answer them. Numbering and hierarchy How do you number your notes? Generally speaking there is little need to number your notes within a digital Zettelkasten. That said, you might want to sequence your notes in order so that they make sense when one note continues on the knowledge of a previous. A good example would be notes about mathematics, where more advanced calculations may be based on previous formulas. You can use a Map of Content to sequence these atomic notes. The notes themselves don’t need any special number or title as their presence in the Map of Content articulates the sequence. A second approach to sequence your notes is to link to the next and previous note in each of the notes. This is what we would refer to as a linked list, where each note links to the next one in the chain. Or you can sequence them together numerically so they can be sorted in a list based on their number. NUMBERING AND HIERARCHY 218 Other methods often used within a Zettelkasten is a timestamp unique identifier in the format of YYYYMMDDHHMM where: YYYY = the current year, for example 2023 MM = the current month, for example 12 for December DD = the current date, for example 31 for the 31st of the month HH = the current hour, for example 23 for 11pm MM = the current minute, for example 15 for a quarter past the hour An example may be 202307101110, representing ten past 11 am on the 10th of July, 2023. This is extremely useful as it ensures the numbers are always unique within an accuracy of a minute. It also indicates when exactly the note was created which means they can easily be sorted chronologically. This is great if you’re daily journaling and want an entry per day. But they don’t describe the sequence of the note within the context of other notes. This is where you might want to consider something like the Folgezettel system, as mentioned earlier. The question you need to ask when it comes to numbering your notes is what problem does it solve. If it’s a way to reference a note without having to use the title (meaning if you change the title but not the link), then something like a Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) might be better. Most applications that store notes in a database rather than a filesystem will usually have some type of ID they use internally. However, they may not let you utilise these IDs for your notes directly as they are generally not very user friendly. Is note hierarchy discouraged? When we think about hierarchy, it’s important to consider what type of hierarchy we are referring to. Traditionally this would be something like a folder structure with files contained inside for the notes. A folder can contain any number of sub folders and files. NUMBERING AND HIERARCHY 219 The main thing to consider is that a single file—a note in our case— can only have one parent. By trying to enforce a hierarchy, it means that you have to decide which parent a given note belongs to. The more sub folders you introduce, the more challenging it becomes to classify where a note should go. Then you might have an idea note that connects two concepts together. You are now stuck as you might feel it equally belongs to two folders. Having folders also creates cognitive friction when adding notes. You have to stop and carefully consider which folder it belongs to. It can get tiresome. It reminds me of the early days using Microsoft Outlook for email. I would try to create folders to capture every type of email I would receive. When it comes to filing those emails, it would be such a mental effort to try and find the most logical place. Often, I would end up with folders containing just one email because it just didn’t fit any of the other folders. Then your system feels odd having some folders with lots of emails and some with just one. Trying to do the same in your Zettelkasten is no different. But does that mean you have no hierarchy at all? Not exactly. After all, what does hierarchy really mean? Your note hierarchy is a way to go from a broad, zoomed out perspective of your notes, all the way down to the highly detailed and refined notes. This can be achieved through the use of your Maps of Content by having nested lists of notes that it can link to. This means you can easily find your high level concept notes, and then see the child detail notes. Another thing to consider is whether you would use hierarchy to organise your notes into the relative topics. Traditionally you might opt for folders for topics like Health, Exercise, Business and NUMBERING AND HIERARCHY 220 Education. But instead you can choose to classify your notes using some form of metadata like a hashtag. This could be #topic/health, #topic/exercise, #topic/business and #topic/education. If a note now belongs to multiple topics, then there is no issue of tagging it multiple times for different topics. You can of course create a topic hierarchy if you desire, for example, #topic/education/teaching. But just be mindful that you could run into the problem of creating a lot of cognitive load trying to classify your notes. Remember, if you can’t do it consistently across your whole Zettelkasten, you’ll lose faith in its reliability. It is better to have something simple that you can trust, than something complex that you can’t trust. Linking How do you create bi-directional links between notes? We mention a lot about linking notes together. It’s become very popular where a lot of note-taking apps allow you to use the double square bracket [[ to signal that you want to link to another note. This is inspired from wiki style links and is an extension to markdown where a [[link]] is a shorthand notation to a local item. Double square brackets are used because single square brackets usually refer to a web link out onto the Internet. Although most apps now automatically detect web links and make them clickable. The way you make links is either inline in your text, or put a section at the bottom which contains a list of related notes. I like to use a “See also” section for related notes and “References” section for links back to the source material. Now, you might see the term bi-directional links and wonder what this really means. It’s very simple. It’s a way for your note-taking app LINKING 221 to search for all other notes that link to the note you’re looking at. It’s a form of reverse search on the link. Bi-directional means the application can show you outbound and inbound links between your notes. This is useful because if you’re making modifications to a note, you can see what other notes link to it and consider if they need to be updated as well. How do you find the right notes to link to? When you’re new to the Zettelkasten you may be wondering when you should be making links. Are you making too many, or too few? The main thing to consider when deciding what to link to is whether in the future—say six months time—there are any notes that would be good to look at next. Imagine what that would be like where you’ve forgotten the detail and you’re discovering the content again with fresh eyes. What are the important related notes that would be good to discover again. Usually notes that contain definitions might not be that useful to link to every time you use the term. For example, if I keep talking about growth mindset, linking to my definition note called “Growth Mindset” wouldn’t be that useful. But if I’ve written a note that touches on some of the understanding of other notes, then that is a great time to put the link in. One example would be a note talking about “making profit as a freelancer” where it would be good to link to “how to budget your finances”. One note builds on the foundational ideas of the other. Try not to link every keyword you have in your note to some other note. This will get overkill and tiresome to manage. Focus on the links that help you discover old notes that have the potential to spark new ideas in the future. LINKING 222 Some apps may try to automatically link to other notes. As AI enters the note-taking space, it might try to do some of this for you. Just be careful. The more you rely on the system automatically doing your thinking for you—you stop thinking. When you stop thinking, you stop thinking deeply about the subject. This limits your ability to make insights from your knowledge. When you make links, you want to make sure you’re able to find notes that are the right ones to link to. Use the search functionality within the app to find related notes that might fit what you want to connect to. This is where having a clear naming convention for your notes is very helpful. The note name should explain exactly what the note is about. This will then give you confidence that the link is correct and useful. How do you connect ideas from different topics together? Being able to connect ideas together from different topics is a fantastic way to create original thinking. But how do you do it? Earlier in the book we introduce the concept of intermediary note ideas. This is where you create an idea note that sits between two related notes. This is fine if you come up with those connections while reading. But what if you want to discover a connection that you haven’t thought of? This is where you can carry out creative exercises that help open up your mind to spot the connections that were previously hidden. The goal is to let your mind wander and explore the connections that are of interest. I find that going for a walk is a brilliant way to help my mind take creative jumps. Often I will solve a difficult problem when I go for a walk. Maybe it’s the increased oxygen to the brain and the change of scenery that helps trigger different neural pathways resulting in divergent thinking. LINKING 223 Other somewhat mindless activities can also help, such as doing the dishes or gardening. It can help to prime your mind with something you’ve been working on. So review some of your most recent notes, think about them, then change your activity to let your mind wander. This is where you naturally think about unrelated concepts and see if they fit together like a puzzle. I have most of my creative ideas when walking. Here are a couple of scenarios where I’ve experienced this creative inspiration: 1. While I was walking along the street, I observed that most cars look the same, but yet they are from completely different companies. I wondered how that was possible. Then I reasoned that the information that makes a car (engine, wheels, seats, general shape) are related, like ancestors in a species. That’s when I let my mind connect the concepts of information and knowledge being like DNA and evolution, where mutations and two-parent offsprings of ideas can happen. You can read the blog post this inspired here: https://meda.io/evolve-your-thinking/ 2. I was listening to an audiobook (possibly Principles by Ray Dalio) and the quote “If you want to know what God thinks of money, just look at who he gives it to” was mentioned. This immediately sparked an idea that I had been loosely thinking about. It’s the idea that the less you care about the outcome, the more likely you will create the outcome. How to choose the right note-taking app for you An Integrated Thinking Environment (ITE) You probably haven’t heard the term ITE before, which refers to an Integrated Thinking Environment. It is similar to the term IDE, which stands for Integrated Development Environment used by software developers. At the core of any note-taking software is the concept of an editor. This could be as simple as Notepad on Windows, or as complex as Obsidian. But as they get more complex, they start to exhibit the features of an ITE. They can be summarised as follows: • Adaptable—You have the ability to adapt the workflows to your own needs. This book is about the Zettelkasten method, but an ITE would allow you to use any method that you like. • Extendable—You have the ability to extend the functionality of the app by using plugins. This usually means that the core app will have some limited functionality, but you have the ability to pick and choose which plugins you want to use to enhance it. HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT NOTE-TAKING APP FOR YOU 257 • Customisable—You have the ability to customise how you experience the app. This might be with different themes or window layouts. • Thinking Tools—The app has the ability to provide tools that help you with your deep thinking. These might be backlinks, graph views, tag management and advanced querying. When looking for the right note-taking app, you want to consider whether it is a simple tool, a highly specialised tool, or a highly customisable tool—such as an ITE. The benefits of an ITE is that you can make it anything you want. The drawbacks of an ITE is that you can make it anything you want. If you’re someone who doesn’t like having to make lots of tiny choices and wants an ‘out of the box’ experience, then an ITE might not be right for you. What you see is what you get (WYSIWYG) The term WYSIWYG—What You See Is What You Get—refers to the text editors that show you what the final version would look like as you type. Microsoft Word is a great example of a WYSIWYG editor where you can literally see the text on a virtual page. This would be different to plain text editors where you cannot visually see the formatting of fonts, colours, bold and italics. If this is something you quite like working with, then a WYSIWYG editor might be the best choice for you. Most note-taking apps work like this, where some have more capabilities than others. Writing your notes in Markdown is a common alternative to WYSIWYG. Markdown as a primary editor Markdown is a simplified text formatting notation that allows you to insert headings, bold, italics, links and various other elements into your text without needing a WYSIWYG editor. HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT NOTE-TAKING APP FOR YOU 258 Some editors allow you to use Markdown as the primary input type, but display it formatted like a WYSIWYG editor. Obsidian fits this category, but you need to know Markdown to apply any formatting. Markdown was created in 2004 by John Gruber in collaboration with Aaron Swartz. It came about at a time where the only popular tool to markup text was to use HTML for presenting on the web. So Markdown was conceived to make it easier to write and format text without having to know or use complex HTML tags or formatting tools. One of the major benefits of using Markdown is that the files are extremely portable. They can be stored on your computer’s file system with the .md extension and can be read using any plain text editor. This is very different to a proprietary WYSIWYG format which requires specialist software to interpret them. Markdown is not for everyone. It is not a visual note-taking format so you can’t use a wide range of font styles, colours or layouts. But it is fast to work with as you can write notes entirely with the keyboard and not need to switch to using a mouse. Long vs short notes The main theme of this book as you’ve guessed by the title is to write atomically. This means your notes should be short and concise. The note-taking apps you choose can either encourage or discourage this. Some apps encourage long form notes, such as Obsidian. Other apps encourage short form notes, such as Tana or Supernotes. Think carefully about how you are using your note-taking software. Are they slipping you into writing longer, more verbose notes that make it harder to manage and reason about? HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT NOTE-TAKING APP FOR YOU 259 Local vs cloud vs hybrid One of the most contentious aspects of any knowledge management software is who owns your notes. While you the user should ‘own’ the notes, this refers to where they are stored. Apps like Notion store your notes entirely in the cloud. If you lose access to your account, you lose access to your notes. Other apps like Obsidian use your file system for all your notes, which means you are responsible for them. There are benefits and drawbacks to each, and there is no right answer as it depends on your own personal preferences. Fully offline apps store your notes on your computer. You have full control over them, but you are responsible for backing them up. They benefit from being fully private as access to your computer would be needed to expose them. But, you may lack the ability to work on different devices as your notes are stored on only one computer. Generally speaking, offline only apps lack revision history as the filesystem is the main and only copy of the notes. The apps could overcome this, but it’s not a common feature. Cloud only apps are where your notes are stored in the cloud. They benefit from being accessible from any compatible device and with the option for collaborative editing with other people. The drawbacks are that you don’t control the notes and they are often in a proprietary format. You may be able to export them, but you have to remember to do it, and what they are exported to as might be difficult to use in another app. These apps are generally monthly subscriptions as it requires cloud hosting. The major drawback though for some is the question of how secure your notes are on their servers. Could a hacker or rogue employee expose the notes? Could a server outage corrupt or lose your notes? HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT NOTE-TAKING APP FOR YOU 260 Then there are hybrid apps. These aim to solve the problem of making the notes accessible and portable at all times. They have the added benefit of synchronising your notes to other devices—usually for a monthly fee. While the question about the security of your notes in the cloud is still relevant, it provides the best all-round benefits of allowing you to be in full control. You have full flexibility over where you can access your notes. As you can see, it is really down to personal preference. The question you need to decide is: 1. Do you value privacy and control over simplicity? 2. Do you value simplicity over privacy? If you worry that someone else might access your notes in the cloud, then opt for an offline only app. If you don’t want to worry about backing up your notes and just want to get on with your knowledge management, then a cloud or hybrid app might be best for you. Desktop, tablet or mobile Another consideration to think about is what device you want to access your notes on. Some apps are desktop only, some are platform specific such as Mac only, and some are web only. If having your notes accessible on your smartphone is critical, then you will probably need a cloud first or hybrid note-taking app. If you know you’ll only be note-taking on your desktop, then a desktop app might be the best choice. If you want to work on your desktop and occasionally on your tablet, then a cloud only or hybrid app might be ideal. So consider where you want to access your notes and what platforms you need it to work with. Also consider your budget.
